Mr. West thought his recent return to Twitter after an almost yearlong hiatus, with relentless contrarian, stream-of consciousness tweets from the minuscule Negro corner of the alt-right world, would read like a takeover of Twitter. But thatís not how the platform works. Black Twitter runs Twitter, and Black Twitter swiftly handed Mr. West his lunch. Mr. West was reading the blowback and did exactly what a person does when he or she is losing ó he dug in. Black Twitter had seen that show before when Mr. West posed for cameras in the lobby of Trump Tower in December 2016 after being hospitalized. The anger at the rapper was because he has allowed himself to be a useful idiot for a useful idiot. Like Mr. Trump, who also brags about not reading books, Mr. West is parroting the racist right-wing talking points he has learned from watching YouTube videos. The same white power wing nuts who trolled him for years as a way of defending Taylor Swiftís honor are now over the moon to hear the rapper blame President Barack Obama for not ameliorating gang violence in Chicago, to see Mr. West at the office of the gossip website TMZ blaming his own enslaved ancestors for their enslavement. Because the trolls won the election, their dangerous drivel sometimes becomes policy, as the musician John Legend tried to tell Mr. West in a series of reasonable texts that Mr. West immediately published. Those talking points from Alex Jones and company perpetuate mass criminalization and incarceration, deportation and worse. When a poll shows 20 percent of Trump supporters would have opposed the freeing of slaves, itís more than a fun punctuation ending the night on cable news. Those talking points run in tandem with textbooks used in Texas schools that describe slaves as ìworkersî and their journey to America as ìimmigration.î The denial of the sadism and brutality of slavery is perpetuated when thereís ìanother sideî arguing to keep statues and symbols of the Confederacy in public places, and when plantation tours explain the generosity with which slave owners cared for their chattel. When Mr. Legend and Mr. West later demonstrated their lasting friendship by publishing pictures of themselves at a baby shower ìdespite their differences,î they advanced the fiction that theirs are two equal but divergent viewpoints. They are not. There is the same old white supremacy that denies black humanity, and there are people who struggle mightily against white supremacy and for black life. It would be unfair to call Mr. Westís public outbursts mere stunts. He was right about the MTV Video Music Awards best female video of 2009. BeyoncÈ should have won. Mr. West was at his most profound in 2005 when he said George Bush doesnít care about black people after that president did a flyby of the poor and black victims of New Orleansís levee failure. When Hurricane Katrina happened, Mr. West was a new artist and his ìCollege Dropoutî was an album that helped give millennials a clear sense of identity. He wrote about being insecure, about not being comfortable managing his new money and visibility. That honesty was refreshing. His self-reflection and self-diagnosis felt familiar to a generation that drafted dozens of confessionals a day on social media. Kids who were in high school and younger when Mr. West made his debut connected with him more than they did with M.C.s like Jay-Z or even Tupac Shakur or Biggie Smalls, who deserve respect but belonged to another era. 50 Cent seemed a Neanderthal compared with the nerdy, backpack-wearing Mr. West. Mr. West rose as the economy collapsed, and his open insecurity spoke to a generation whose struggle was the housing market collapse, not a crack epidemic. He is the son of a single mother, a professor who raised him abroad for a semester or two in China. His story was more like President Obamaís than 50 Centís. This new generation didnít necessarily believe in crowns, but Mr. West was their guy, and almost immediately after being chosen, he began to collapse from the pressure. Weíve seen Mr. West melt down before. His 2013 radio interview with the journalist Sway was as unhinged as Mr. Trumpís recent call-in to ìFox & Friends.î Mr. Trump and Mr. West both seemed to want the same thing in those tirades ó to be recognized as gods. Mr. Trump roared into the phone about the Breitbart calculator he uses to argue voter fraud cost him the popular vote. The rapper screamed at Sway, who seemed unwilling to concede that Mr. West is the greatest artist of his generation. Or maybe Mr. West was arguing he was the greatest artist of any generation. Itís hard to remember. We got a harmless new pop culture refrain from the interview ó ìHow, Sway?î ó and mostly moved on. But unlike Mr. Trumpís call, Mr. Westís interview with Sway was videotaped. We were witnessing something more than his outsize ego doing battle with his mammoth insecurity. His refusal to make eye contact with Sway was particularly off-putting. He spent the hour talking to the heavens ó not to the interviewer, not even to the audience. Absent was the wink and nod embedded in Muhammad Aliís news conference performances, where he talked about himself in the third person and invented the kind of braggadocio that would become hip-hopís bedrock. Watching Mr. West during that interview, some of us began to worry about his mental health. Like most of his fans, Iím not qualified or interested in actually attempting to diagnose an illness in Mr. West. He has shared with us that he has been medicated and hospitalized. He has also told us that his recent Twitter rant is unconnected to his mental health, that he is fine. His performance at TMZ was similar to his interview with Sway. It wasnít until Van Lathan, on the staff there, interrupted to take him on about slavery that Mr. West even seemed present in the room, and that was truly heartbreaking to watch. But what was dangerous was the way Mr. West included Candace Owens, an alt-right darling, a black woman and puppet, on his broadcast from the TMZ office. Her participation was most likely arranged by alt-right operatives. A Black Lives Matter strategist hypothesized as much on his Facebook page when he noticed white power operatives taking credit for connecting the two. With uncharacteristic generosity, Mr. West ceded the mic to Ms. Owens, who allows a racist, misogynist movement to hold her up as evidence that it is neither. Mr. Trumpís speechwriters made sure to include Mr. West in his recent speech to the National Rifle Association, thanking the rapper for ìdoublingî his approval numbers among black people. He was referring to a real poll, but he got it wrong. The doubling was only among black men, from 11 percent to 22 percent (with a margin of error of nine points). Mr. West barely owned the entire week. R. Kelly had some karma delivered to his front door, and the fascist, feeble Rudy Giuliani had his moments, embarrassing himself. But Mr. Westís shrill missives from the monochromatic sunken place that is his mansion may be consequential in ways he canít fathom.

headline: Elon Musk Wants to Fill Warren Buffettís ëMoatí With Candy, but It Still Holds Water
description: Mr. Musk is the business worldís gleeful invader, but Mr. Buffettís mantra of investing in businesses with ìmoatsî remains secure.
author: Andrew Ross Sorkin
topic_tags: Warren Buffett, Elon Musk, Berkshire Hathaway, Tesla, Regulation and Deregulation, Venture capital
text: OMAHA ó Elon Musk is taking on Warren Buffett, and their differences run deeper than jokes about candy and medieval fortifications. At Berkshire Hathawayís annual meeting over the weekend, I relayed a question from a shareholder to Mr. Buffett about a comment Mr. Musk had made a couple days earlier. ìI think ëmoatsí are lame,î Mr. Musk had said during a Tesla earnings call. It was a criticism of economic principle Mr. Buffett that coined in 1999 and that has become something of a mantra for his faithful: Invest in businesses ìthat have wide, sustainable moats around them.î Such moats, Mr. Buffett has said, are made of the competitive advantages that benefit major brands and companies, like distribution networks, pricing power and brand reputation. But to Mr. Musk, they are a metaphor for being stuck in the past. ìIf your only defense against invading armies is a moat, you will not last long,î he said. ìWhat matters is the pace of innovation ó that is the fundamental determinant of competitiveness.î At a time when technology is upending even old-line industries that once seemed impenetrable to competition, might Mr. Musk be right? ìElon may turn things upside down in some areas,î Mr. Buffett said. ìI donít think heíd want to take us on in candy,î suggesting Berkshireís Seeís Candies division enjoyed an unassailably wide moat. The quip elicited laughter from the 20,000 shareholders who packed the CenturyLink Center. Mr. Musk answered the challenge immediately, saying he was starting a candy company. ìAnd itís going to be amazing,î he wrote on Twitter. Not only that, Mr. Musk said, he planned ìto build a moat and fill it with candyî ó making it impossible for Mr. Buffett to resist sinking his money into the venture. The repartee was good for some chuckles and clickbait headlines, but the mini-spat masked a more serious and significant debate taking place across corporate America: Have the traditional moats shrunk? When direct-to-consumer brands like Dollar Shave Club have been able to take on consumer giants like Procter & Gambleís Gillette ó so much so that Unilever bought Dollar Shave Club for $1 billion ó are any businesses still safe? Mr. Buffett owns Kraft Heinz, for example, but could upstart food companies one day overtake it, breaking through the substantial network of distribution and marketing arrangements ó and brand loyalty ó that Kraft Heinz has built up over decades? Mr. Buffett acknowledged that times had changed. ìThere have been more moats that have become susceptible to invasion than seemed to be the case earlier,î he said. To a large degree, Mr. Musk is a living embodiment of a gleeful invader. With Tesla, he is trying to prove that what was long thought of as a substantial moat around the automobile industry could be overcome. He has gone direct to consumer with Tesla vehicles, bypassing the traditional car dealers that were once considered a barrier to entering the automotive business. He even had what seemed like his own moat: a network of Supercharger stations around the country that he recently opened up to competitors. (His initial panning of the ìmoatî idea followed a question about why he was willing to cede the advantage that the closed charging network provided.) But, in truth, Mr. Muskís experience ó and challenges ó at Tesla may demonstrate just how much a moat remains a powerful deterrent to competitors. In the case of the automobile industry, perhaps the biggest barrier is the huge amount of capital needed ó Tesla has already raised more than $12 billion. But even with huge amounts of money, Teslaís recent production struggles ó it has repeatedly missed its targets for making the new mass-market Model 3 ó show the immense value of manufacturing experience. Mr. Muskís willingness to challenge convention has clearly pushed the automobile industry forward, but his progress has lately been bumpier than he initially expected. Thatís not to say he wonít succeed, but if he does, he may be the exception, not the rule. There are still huge swaths of our economy that have dauntingly wide moats, many of them protected by regulatory walls. Banks, which have been speculated about as ripe for disruption by financial technology companies, seem more likely to buy start-ups than compete against them. Airlines ó which Mr. Buffett once called ìa death trap for investorsî ó have consolidated, and enormous corporations control virtually all the landing slots at airports around the globe. Before it could get off the ground, any insurgent hoping to challenge them would have to find a spot to come down. Even many digital businesses have a moat: Google and Facebook control so much of the advertising market that it is hard to see how a kid in a garage with an idea could usurp them anytime soon. Amazon has itself has become so powerful that virtually every seller feels it has to go through it. And Mr. Buffett has convinced himself that Appleís deep relationship with its customers through its ecosystem of products and iCloud mean the business has a defensible moat. ìThere are some pretty good moats around,î Mr. Buffett said. ìBeing the low-cost producer, for example, is a terribly important moat,î he said, citing Geico, the low-cost insurance company Berkshire owns. Saturday night, after the Berkshire meeting ended, Mr. Musk was still tweeting: ìSaying you like ëmoatsí is just a nice way of saying you like oligopolies.î For better or worse, the limited competition that oligopolies face is usually good for investors ó even if consumers might disagree. But whether they have been dug by a companyís experienced hand, the good will of its customers or the heavy machinery of governmental regulation, moats remain a formidable form of protection, even from the most willing of raiders. Perhaps Charlie Munger, Berkshireís vice chairman, put it best: ìElon says a conventional moat is quaint. And thatís true of a puddle of water.î

headline: The Wreckage Schneiderman Leaves Behind
description: New Yorkers deserve the chance to choose a law enforcement leader who will be honest, independent and moral.
author: The Editorial Board
topic_tags: Legislation, Attorney general, Domestic violence, MeToo Movement, Women's rights;Feminism, New Yorker, Michelle Manning Barish, Eric T Schneiderman, Barbara D Underwood, NYC
text: In the space of a few short hours on Monday evening, Eric Schneiderman went from being known as one of the nationís most progressive and influential attorneys general to being cast as a drunken, abusive monster who terrorized women in his personal life even as he publicly advocated womenís rights. The immediate question before New Yorkers is who takes over what has become one of the key law enforcement posts in the country. What canít happen is for lawmakers in Albany to concoct a back-room deal to install someone they think will further their political games rather than the cause of justice. Until voters have a chance to pick a new attorney general in the fall, the clear choice is Barbara Underwood, the stateís solicitor general, who becomes acting attorney general upon Mr. Schneidermanís formal resignation Tuesday afternoon. Ms. Underwood has a stellar reputation and extensive experience as a litigator, and would carry on the work of the office until the election. There are other questions ó about Mr. Schneiderman himself, about domestic violence and law enforcement, about power and gender in general ó for us all to consider. Mr. Schneidermanís fall was so fast, the allegations against him so appalling and the depth of his apparent hypocrisy so astounding that the lesson will take some time to sort out. But it is already clear that his betrayal operates on at least three levels. First and most important is the betrayal of the women who were romantically involved with Mr. Schneiderman and who told The New Yorker of the physical and emotional abuse he inflicted on them. Their descriptions ó of his choking, slapping, spitting, threatening their lives, insulting their bodies, mocking their professional ambitions and trying to control their appearance ó are horrendous. In a statement Monday night, Mr. Schneiderman flatly denied assaulting anyone or engaging in nonconsensual sex but said, ìI have engaged in role-playing and other consensual sexual activity.î The four women who have come forward so far evidently did not experience it that way. The next betrayal is of Mr. Schneidermanís office, of his position as New Yorkís top law enforcement official and of his obligation to uphold the rule of law. According to his accusers, Mr. Schneiderman appeared to enjoy exploiting his authority to threaten and terrify them into silence. One former girlfriend, Michelle Manning Barish, recalled that one time, after Mr. Schneiderman violently struck her, he accused her of scratching him and said, ìYou know, hitting an officer of the law is a felony.î Another time, she said, he pulled her across the street, and when she said jaywalking was against the law, he responded, ìI am the law.î Mr. Schneiderman might say comments like those were meant in jest, but the blood and bruises the women reported suggest otherwise. In this regard, Mr. Schneidermanís case may be the most egregious yet of the #MeToo era. As one of Mr. Schneidermanís accusers told The New Yorker, ìWhat do you do if your abuser is the top law enforcement official in the state?î Itís a good question, and one that is sadly too common. Domestic violence in law enforcement families occurs at two to four times the rate in American families generally, according to the National Center for Women and Policing. In many cases, officers who abuse are not punished, and are even protected by colleagues and supervisors. Itís not yet clear how many people knew of Mr. Schneidermanís alleged behavior, but these accusations come as such a shock in large part because of the values Mr. Schneiderman professed to hold. This irony is at the heart of his final betrayal. Mr. Schneiderman made womenís rights a centerpiece of his agenda, going back to his time as a New York state senator, when he introduced legislation that made life-threatening strangulation a violent felony. He praised the ìbrave women and men who spoke upî about the sexual harassment they suffered, and the ìcritical national reckoningî brought about by the exposure of Harvey Weinstein and other powerful men. His office had even begun an investigation of the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus Vance Jr., for his decision not to prosecute Mr. Weinstein in 2015 following a womanís accusation that he had groped her. In yet another layer of irony, Mr. Vance is now investigating the allegations against Mr. Schneiderman, whose Manhattan apartment was allegedly the site of many of the acts. Certainly an inquiry is warranted, although given the recent history between these two offices, it might be more appropriately handled by someone else. After the 2016 election, Mr. Schneiderman styled himself as an avatar of the resistance to President Trumpís agenda, bringing more than a hundred actions against the administration. As recently as last week, he was pushing to change New York law to allow for state prosecutions of Trump aides in case the president pardoned them for federal crimes. (Speaking of Mr. Trumpís supporters, they are the last people who should be gloating about the downfall of a sexual abuser.) In the coming weeks and months, many qualified people will consider running for attorney general. We look forward to a competitive primary that delivers the honest, independent, moral ó and perhaps for a change, female ó law enforcement leader New Yorkers need. As Mr. Schneiderman said just a few days ago, ìIf a woman cannot control her body, she is not truly equal.î The state deserves an attorney general who will live by those words.

headline: Eric Schneiderman Set Himself Up as Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Foil. What Happens Now?
description: The attorney general had made his name since 2016 a crusader against Mr. Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s agenda and a counterweight to the presidential pardon powers.
author: Shane Goldmacher, Alan Feuer
topic_tags: US Politics, Attorney general, Amnesties Commutations and Pardons, Eric T Schneiderman, Donald Trump
text: For the last 17 months, Eric T. Schneiderman, the attorney general of New York, had held himself up as the anti-Trump: a one-man legal battering ram, taking on the president and his agenda in both the courts and the court of public opinion. His sudden and spectacular downfall ‚<U+0080><U+0094> Mr. Schneiderman announced his resignation hours after four women emerged to describe in detail how he had physically assaulted them ‚<U+0080><U+0094> has raised questions of whether a powerful office at the heart of the Democratic legal resistance could be sidelined and besmirched by scandal. Some have even held up Mr. Schneiderman as a potential backstop to prosecute crimes should President Trump choose to pardon his associates in the ongoing special counsel investigation led by Robert S. Mueller III. The president‚<U+0080><U+0099>s vast federal pardoning powers do not apply to violation of state laws. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>If you imagine a next attorney general in New York who is not as interested in being the big anti-Trump figure, that‚<U+0080><U+0099>s a potentially significant difference, ‚<U+0080>ù said Benjamin Wittes, a Brookings Institution senior fellow and the editor in chief of LawFare. Advertisement G. Oliver Koppell, who served as New York attorney general for one year in the 1990s, said much of the office‚<U+0080><U+0099>s direction ‚<U+0080><U+009C>depends on the personality‚<U+0080>ù of its leader. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Eric was very aggressive in challenging the Trump agenda in all sorts of ways, and it‚<U+0080><U+0099>s very difficult to predict what the next attorney general will pursue, ‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Koppell said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>I don‚<U+0080><U+0099>t know if the next attorney general will be equally aggressive.‚<U+0080>ù [Who will be the next attorney general? Here are some of the leading contenders.] Mr. Trump sparred with Mr. Schneiderman long before he became president, including about a civil investigation into Trump University that resulted in a $25 million settlement. Mr. Schneiderman had also opened an investigation into the Donald J. Trump Foundation in 2016 and then the Eric Trump Foundation in 2017. After Mr. Schneiderman‚<U+0080><U+0099>s resignation, allies of Mr. Trump cheered his demise. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Gotcha, ‚<U+0080>ù tweeted Kellyanne Conway, counselor to the president, digging up an old tweet from Mr. Schneiderman in which he had reminded the president that ‚<U+0080><U+009C>no one is above the law.‚<U+0080>ù Donald Trump Jr., the president‚<U+0080><U+0099>s son, tweeted about Mr. Schneiderman no less than 10 times late Monday and early Tuesday. Mr. Schneiderman had focused intensely on Mr. Trump since the day after the 2016 election, when he said he gathered staff in Manhattan to discuss reorienting their whole operation. Since then, Mr. Schneiderman had engaged in dozens of lawsuits and administrative actions to challenge Mr. Trump from the earliest days of the administration. So will Mr. Schneiderman‚<U+0080><U+0099>s abrupt exit leave a vacuum for Democrats, either politically or legally? ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The short answer is the work goes on, ‚<U+0080>ù said Sean Rankin, the executive director of the Democratic Attorneys General Association. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It does not slow down.‚<U+0080>ù Advertisement Even though Mr. Schneiderman has often served as the public face of the sprawling legal battles against Mr. Trump, Mr. Rankin said that his organization had already devised a strategy to share responsibility for the various lawsuits against the president‚<U+0080><U+0099>s policies. Doug Chin, the attorney general of Hawaii, for instance, took the lead against Mr. Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s travel ban, Mr. Rankin said, and Xavier Becerra, California‚<U+0080><U+0099>s attorney general, stepped to the front in fighting back against the president‚<U+0080><U+0099>s attempts to repeal President Barack Obama‚<U+0080><U+0099>s signature health care law. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>States are protecting their people, values and economy, and that will continue as leaders throughout the country continue to emerge to resist and persist, ‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Becerra said in a statement. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Nothing is going to change, ‚<U+0080>ù predicted James E. Tierney, a former attorney general of Maine who is now a lecturer at Harvard Law School. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>No change ‚<U+0080><U+0094> zero.‚<U+0080>ù Still, the attorney general of New York, the home to Mr. Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s businesses, his family and his campaign, is uniquely well suited to playing an outsize role in legal matters involving the president. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. In particular, Mr. Schneiderman had positioned his office as a fail-safe in the special counsel‚<U+0080><U+0099>s probe. In recent weeks, Mr. Schneiderman had sought to exempt New York‚<U+0080><U+0099>s double-jeopardy law from cases that involved presidential pardons. But now he is the subject of a criminal investigation, begun Tuesday by the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr. The future of that inquiry remained in doubt after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said he was considering appointing a special prosecutor to look into the charges. For the time being, the office of attorney general will be taken over by Barbara Underwood, who has served as New York‚<U+0080><U+0099>s solicitor general for a decade, and who is respected in the legal community, though not seen as particularly political. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>She is not someone who has had experience rushing up to a political podium to inveigh against the so-called forces of evil, ‚<U+0080>ù said Seth W. Waxman, who worked with Ms. Underwood when he served as solicitor general under President Bill Clinton. With Mr. Schneiderman out and Ms. Underwood in, some Democratic attorneys general from across the country discussed the new legal landscape on their regular weekly call on Tuesday. Advertisement ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The A.G.s and I spoke about her today, ‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Rankin said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>She‚<U+0080><U+0099>s got a tremendous reputation. They‚<U+0080><U+0099>re looking forward to working with her.‚<U+0080>ù She could also be not long in the job: State legislators gathered in Albany on Tuesday, less than 12 hours after Mr. Schneiderman announced he would step down, to discuss whom they want to appoint to fill out his term. A long list of Democrats have already begun jockeying behind the scenes to either win appointment or run for one of the plum jobs in New York politics. The primaries will be held in September. Mr. Wittes, the Brookings Institution fellow, said playing the role of anti-Trump would likely appeal to any Democrat who becomes attorney general. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Using that position as a launching pad for higher political ambition by opposing Trump is going to be an irresistible opportunity for some Democratic lawyer, ‚<U+0080>ù he said. For Mr. Trump, the resignation represented a welcome end to an elected official he donated to in 2010 but turned against as Mr. Schneiderman began to investigate his business practices, calling him ‚<U+0080><U+009C>incompetent, ‚<U+0080>ù a ‚<U+0080><U+009C>hack‚<U+0080>ù and a ‚<U+0080><U+009C>shakedown artist.‚<U+0080>ù In 2013, he compared Mr. Schneiderman unfavorably to two other Democratic politicians felled by scandal: former Representative Anthony Weiner and former Gov. Eliot Spitzer. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Weiner is gone, Spitzer is gone ‚<U+0080><U+0094> next will be lightweight A.G. Eric Schneiderman. Is he a crook? Wait and see, worse than Spitzer or Weiner, ‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Trump wrote then. As a result of the insults, investigations and lawsuits, Mr. Schneiderman emerged as the most visible attorney general taking on Mr. Trump ‚<U+0080><U+0094> much to the delight of Democrats. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>You are a super hero, ‚<U+0080>ù the late-night comedian Samantha Bee told him on her show last fall. During the segment, she featured Mr. Schneiderman on a series of faux comic book covers battling Mr. Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s agenda. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>With great power, ‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Schneiderman quoted the famous Spiderman line back to her, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>comes great responsibility.‚<U+0080>ù

What does it say to all survivors?‚<U+0080>ù ‚<U+0080><U+0094> Brenda Tracy, a victims‚<U+0080><U+0099> rights activist, on fans who cheer for Luke Heimlich, a star college pitcher who pleaded guilty to sexually molesting his 6-year-old niece when he was 15, but now denies wrongdoing. ‚<U+0080>¢ The Times, in other words Here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s an image of today‚<U+0080><U+0099>s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles. Obviously, I‚<U+0080><U+0099>m not the only one. This goes even further, and delves into whether animals engage in economic activity ‚<U+0080><U+0094> can a dog make a fair and deliberate exchange of one bone with another dog?‚<U+0080>ù When the contestants in the Eurovision Song Contest take the stage in Lisbon starting today, they will be part of a giant edition of the zany annual pop competition. Forty-three countries will compete for the prize, which will be awarded in a grand final on Saturday. At the first contest in Switzerland in 1956, there were just 14 entries ‚<U+0080><U+0094> two each from seven West European nations. But socialist Yugoslavia joined in 1961, and the competition since then has become ever more international and inclusive. Israel first appeared in 1973; Australia, which had broadcast the competition without taking part since the 1980s, has been sending contestants since 2015. Despite its distinctly ‚<U+0080><U+009C>euro‚<U+0080>ù sensibility ‚<U+0080><U+0094> which can be puzzling to the uninitiated ‚<U+0080><U+0094> Eurovision is now a global phenomenon with fans all over the world. In the U.S., Eurovision has found perhaps its most enthusiastic audience among gay men. Ricardo Mohammed, who is originally from Trinidad, holds Eurovision viewing and dance parties at a gay bar in Manhattan. ‚<U+0080><U+009C> ‚<U+0080><U+0098>What the hell is going on?‚<U+0080><U+0099> is the first reaction, ‚<U+0080>ù he said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The second is, ‚<U+0080><U+0098>Why is everybody on the dance floor and singing along?‚<U+0080><U+0099> ‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Mohammed laughed. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>That‚<U+0080><U+0099>s pretty consistent with Americans reacting to Eurovision for the first time.‚<U+0080>ù Advertisement Matthew Anderson and Elisabeth Vincentelli wrote today‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Back Story. _____ Your Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. headline: Him, Too
description: Eric Schneiderman stands accused of the very sorts of abuse he claimed to fight as state attorney general. Now itís up to legislators to pick a true champion.
author: The Editorial Board
topic_tags: Rape, US Politics, State legislature, MeToo Movement, Democrats, Eric T Schneiderman, New York
text: Until Monday evening New Yorkís Attorney General Eric Schneiderman was a public champion of the #MeToo movement. Now he appears to be the latest sickening example of the scale and insidiousness of the cruelty that movement is confronting. He resigned late Monday after The New Yorker magazine published an article in which four women accused him of abusing them physically and emotionally. Gov. Andrew Cuomo should appoint a responsible, independent prosecutor to investigate any possible criminal charges against Mr. Schneiderman and abuses of his office. Mr. Schneiderman admitted no wrongdoing. Instead, he said in a statement that the ìserious allegations, which I strongly contest,î had made it impossible to do his job. But the allegations outlined by the women are consistent, detailed and bone-chilling. Two women who had been in relationships with Mr. Schneiderman ó Michelle Manning Barish, a liberal activist, and Tanya Selvaratnam, an author ó told the magazine that he choked and hit them, often during sex, and subjected them to verbal abuse. They said he slapped them so hard that Ms. Manning Barish bled from her ear long after the blow, while Ms. Selvaratnam suffered from episodes of vertigo. Both said Mr. Schneiderman threatened to kill them, while Ms. Selvaratnam said the state attorney also warned her he could have her followed and her phone tapped. The women told The New Yorker that Mr. Schneiderman drank heavily, and would often force them to drink alcohol. Ms. Selvaratnam told the magazine Mr. Schneiderman called her his ìbrown slave,î and forced her to say that she was, ìhis property.î Mr. Schneiderman joins a sorry list of once-rising stars in New Yorkís Democratic Party whose careers imploded amid allegations of personal misconduct, including former Gov. Eliot Spitzer and former Congressman Anthony Weiner. As was the case with those men, the resignation of Mr. Schneiderman could have far-reaching consequences. The attorney general was in the midst of pushing a proposal to change New Yorkís double jeopardy statute so any aides to President Trump that he might pardon ó in an effort to keep them from cooperating with the special counsel ó could be prosecuted under state charges. Mr. Schneidermanís moralizing may have proven hollow, but that proposal remains worthy given Mr. Trumpís continual attempts to derail the special counselís investigation, including raising the prospect of such pardons. Mr. Schneidermanís office this year also brought a civil rights lawsuit against Harvey Weinstein, the movie producer accused of sexual assault and other misconduct. Under state law, the Senate and Assembly will jointly choose Mr. Schneidermanís replacement, effectively giving the power to his fellow Democrats. Later, voters will go to the polls in the Democratic primary, and have their say about who would face the Republican candidate in November. Whoever serves in this important office should be tough and independent, willing to stand up to Mr. Trump and Mr. Cuomo and ó it should go without saying, but now it needs to be said ó be a decent human being. Anyone involved in the effort to replace Mr. Schneiderman should remember: No one is above the law.

headline: Schneiderman‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Resignation Leads to Turmoil and Speculation About His Successor
description: Allegations that the New York attorney general abused multiple women set off a torrent of condemnations and questions about who would replace him.
author: Vivian Wang
topic_tags: Attorney general, Eric T Schneiderman, New York, Andrew Cuomo
text: The resignation of Eric T. Schneiderman, New York‚<U+0080><U+0099>s attorney general and a central figure in the liberal resistance to President Trump, after allegations that he had physically abused multiple women set off an immediate storm of speculation in New York about his potential successor, and raised questions nationwide about the fate of his legal challenges to the Trump administration. Even before Mr. Schneiderman announced his resignation late Monday evening, just hours after The New Yorker first published the accusations, New York‚<U+0080><U+0099>s political circles were already abuzz with talk of who would replace him. He had been the heavy favorite to win a third term in November. Until the election, the vacancy will be filled by the State Assembly and State Senate, which under New York‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Constitution make the choice by joint ballot. That effectively places the decision in the hands of the Assembly, which comprises an overwhelming majority of the state‚<U+0080><U+0099>s legislators and is dominated by Democrats ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The effective choice is with the Speaker, ‚<U+0080>ù said Gerald Benjamin, a political science professor at SUNY-New Paltz, referring to Carl E. Heastie, the leader of the Assembly Democrats. Advertisement Names of potential successors proliferated quickly and included Kathleen Rice, a United States representative from Long Island who unsuccessfully challenged Mr. Schneiderman in the 2010 Democratic primary; Preet Bharara, the former United States attorney from Manhattan; Alphonso David, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo‚<U+0080><U+0099>s chief counsel; Michael Gianaris, a state senator from Queens and chief political strategist for the Democratic conference; Zephyr Teachout, a Fordham Law School professor who ran for governor in 2014; Helene Weinstein, who chairs the Assembly‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Ways and Means Committee; and Benjamin Lawsky, formerly the state‚<U+0080><U+0099>s top financial regulator. None have publicly expressed interest, and it is unclear whether they would also seek to run in the general election in November. The Assembly Democrats were scheduled to meet on Tuesday morning to discuss the choice. New York‚<U+0080><U+0099>s solicitor general, Barbara D. Underwood, will lead the office in the meantime, according to Amy Spitalnick, a spokeswoman for the attorney general‚<U+0080><U+0099>s office. Ms. Underwood, a graduate of Harvard and Georgetown, has argued 20 cases before the Supreme Court and served as a clerk for former Justice Thurgood Marshall. According to The New Yorker, Mr. Schneiderman slapped, choked or spat on at least four women with whom he had been romantically involved, two of whom spoke on the record. The horrific accusations included alcohol-fueled rages, racist remarks, drug abuse and threats ‚<U+0080><U+0094> including to kill the women or use his power as the state‚<U+0080><U+0099>s top law enforcement officer against them if they defied him. Politicians and pundits in both parties joined in swift and unsparing condemnation of Mr. Schneiderman. But the conversation quickly turned partisan, given Mr. Schneiderman‚<U+0080><U+0099>s meteoric rise as a relentless and outspoken legal foe of Mr. Trump who had sued the federal administration more than 100 times over policies ranging from immigration to taxation. Prominent Republicans nationwide reveled in the news. Donald Trump Jr. mockingly shared several old tweets from the attorney general, in which he had denounced the president and expressed solidarity with victims of sexual assault; ‚<U+0080><U+009C>This didn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t age well, ‚<U+0080>ù he wrote. Kellyanne Conway, the president‚<U+0080><U+0099>s counselor, wrote in a tweet that Mr. Schneiderman had been ‚<U+0080><U+009C>drunk with power.‚<U+0080>ù By early Tuesday, the president had not commented on Mr. Schneiderman‚<U+0080><U+0099>s resignation. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. Mr. Schneiderman‚<U+0080><U+0099>s fellow Democrats had also called on him to step aside, with Mr. Cuomo, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand and Mr. Heastie saying the attorney general was incapable of continuing in his office. And people in both parties were quick to point out that some right-wing pundits who blasted the attorney general were also staunch defenders of President Trump, who has himself been accused of a slew of sexual abuse. While Mr. Schneiderman‚<U+0080><U+0099>s resignation signals the probable end of a career that many had seen as gaining quick national prominence, the legal fallout is most likely only beginning. Advertisement A spokesman for Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, said Mr. Vance‚<U+0080><U+0099>s office had opened an investigation into the allegations in the New Yorker article. Mr. Schneiderman had, at the direction of Mr. Cuomo, himself been probing Mr. Vance‚<U+0080><U+0099>s office over questions about its handling of groping allegations against the film mogul Harvey Weinstein in 2015. A spokeswoman for the attorney general‚<U+0080><U+0099>s office did not immediately comment on whether that review would continue. Separately, Mr. Cuomo also said on Monday that he would direct an ‚<U+0080><U+009C>appropriate New York district attorney‚<U+0080>ù to investigate the allegations. An administration official said Monday that the governor‚<U+0080><U+0099>s office wanted to avoid any conflict of interest and ensure the proper jurisdiction, given the attorney general‚<U+0080><U+0099>s review of Mr. Vance and the fact that some of the alleged abuse occurred on Long Island. Mr. Schneiderman had been in contact with a criminal defense lawyer late Monday afternoon to advise him on his response to The New Yorker, according to two people with knowledge of the matter. Later, an associate of Mr. Schneiderman was looking for a lawyer to represent him in connection with the criminal investigation, several other people with knowledge of the matter said. Mr. Schneiderman has denied wrongdoing, describing the acts as part of consensual relationships. Several women‚<U+0080><U+0099>s groups that had previously supported Mr. Schneiderman ‚<U+0080><U+0094> he was known for being an outspoken advocate for women‚<U+0080><U+0099>s advancement, especially reproductive rights ‚<U+0080><U+0094> expressed shock and sorrow. The National Institute for Reproductive Health, which had honored the attorney general at a May 1 luncheon, said in a statement that it was ‚<U+0080><U+009C>appalled and horrified.‚<U+0080>ù (By Tuesday, the group had removed Mr. Schneiderman from its list of honorees.) Sonia Ossorio, president of New York‚<U+0080><U+0099>s arm of the National Organization for Women, which endorsed Mr. Schneiderman in his 2010 and 2014 campaigns, said she was ‚<U+0080><U+009C>in shock.‚<U+0080>ù ‚<U+0080><U+009C>I‚<U+0080><U+0099>m just beside myself right now, ‚<U+0080>ù she said. And political observers said the news would further erode public trust in Albany, which has been roiled repeatedly by corruption trials, sexual harassment scandals and other ethics controversies. Douglas Muzzio, a political science professor at Baruch College, said the allegations were ‚<U+0080><U+009C>another blow‚<U+0080>ù to our ‚<U+0080><U+009C>trust in government officials and in the institutions of government itself.‚<U+0080>ù Follow Vivian Wang on Twitter: @vwang3 William K. Rashbaum contributed reporting

headline: New York Attorney General‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Comments on Women‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Rights
description: Before he resigned Monday after four former romantic partners accused him of physical assault, Eric T. Schneiderman was known as an advocate for women.
author: Austin Ramzy
topic_tags: Women's rights;Feminism, Eric T Schneiderman, MeToo Movement, Sexual harassment, Violence Against Women Act, New Yorker, Weinstein, Harvey Weinstein, Domestic violence
text: Before his abrupt resignation Monday after four women accused him of physical assault, Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York cultivated an image as an advocate for women. Here are some of his own recent comments about gender equality, abortion rights, and sexual harassment and assault. On the 20th anniversary of the Violence Against Women Act in 2014, Mr. Schneiderman said that despite legislation, threats to women‚<U+0080><U+0099>s physical safety remained a problem across the country. He said in a written statement: ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Twenty years ago today, President Bill Clinton signed into law the Violence Against Women Act, a major milestone in our nation‚<U+0080><U+0099>s efforts to prevent violence against women and help the victims of such reprehensible acts. But two decades later, despite the significant protections established under VAWA, recent events have shone necessary light on the fact that violence against women remains a prevalent and dangerous problem across our nation. Basic safety is not a privilege: It is a fundamental right. Protecting all Americans from harm, regardless of their relationship to their abuser or their gender, is and will remain one of the most important aspects of our ongoing pursuit of equal justice under law.‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Schneiderman‚<U+0080><U+0099>s office published a brochure to inform victims of domestic violence of their rights under state and federal law. Advertisement In announcing an updated brochure in 2016, he said: ‚<U+0080><U+009C>We‚<U+0080><U+0099>ve made tremendous progress protecting victims of domestic violence through enhanced legal protections and enforcement actions. Yet this month, we must recognize that our work keeping New Yorkers safe from domestic violence is far from over. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>We know that domestic violence victims are often some of the most vulnerable residents of our state. Our hope is that our enforcement actions, as well as our education and outreach efforts, will assist domestic violence victims to escape the violence they face at the hands of their abusers and assist them in building safe, productive lives.‚<U+0080>ù On May 1, Mr. Schneiderman was honored by the National Institute for Reproductive Health at its annual Champions of Choice luncheon. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>If a woman cannot control her body, she is not truly equal, ‚<U+0080>ù he said. He added: ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The federal government has been taken over by anti-choice and anti-women extremists. We need to reimagine the pro-choice movement and build a stronger, louder movement for women‚<U+0080><U+0099>s freedom and equality than we‚<U+0080><U+0099>ve ever seen. Movement politics is not the politics of accommodation, it is the politics of perseverance.‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Schneiderman was a vocal supporter of the Affordable Care Act, and he saw his defense of President Obama‚<U+0080><U+0099>s policy to expand health care coverage as a protection of women‚<U+0080><U+0099>s rights. He told GQ magazine last year: ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It‚<U+0080><U+0099>s important to keep in mind that in one respect the health care fight is part of a wider effort by radical conservatives to oppress and disempower women. Denying women access to contraception and abortion services is a critical part of the larger machinery of oppression, discrimination, and violence against women and it‚<U+0080><U+0099>s incumbent on all of us to fight.‚<U+0080>ù After the Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein was accused of sexual misconduct by dozens of women, Mr. Schneiderman filed a lawsuit against Mr. Weinstein, his brother, Bob, and their studio. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>We have never seen anything as despicable as what we‚<U+0080><U+0099>ve seen right here, ‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Schneiderman said in announcing the civil rights suit. He said at a news conference: ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Our investigation uncovered a pervasive pattern of sexual harassment, intimidation, discrimination and abuse at the Weinstein Company. Women were coerced into facilitating Harvey Weinstein‚<U+0080><U+0099>s misconduct. Sometimes they were targets themselves. If they refused they were threatened with insults. Their careers were threatened. They were threatened with physical intimidation and violence.‚<U+0080>ù He added: ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The board and management knew all of this. They knew how pervasive it was, and not only did they fail to stop it, they enabled it and covered it up.‚<U+0080>ù Last month, after Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey of the The New York Times and Ronan Farrow of The New Yorker were awarded the Pulitzer Prize in public service for their reporting on Harvey Weinstein, Mr. Schneiderman praised their work in a tweet. Without such reporting, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>and the brave women and men who spoke up about the sexual harassment they endured at the hands of powerful men ‚<U+0080><U+0094> there would not be the critical national reckoning underway, ‚<U+0080>ù he wrote. Without the reporting of the @nytimes and the @newyorker‚<U+0080><U+0094>and the brave women and men who spoke up about the sexual harassment they endured at the hands of powerful men‚<U+0080><U+0094>there would not be the critical national reckoning underway. A well-deserved honor: https://t.co/h4QMPzEU5c Mr. Farrow was one of the reporters on The New Yorker story Monday that first reported the four women‚<U+0080><U+0099>s allegations of violence by Mr. Schneiderman.

headline: Fighting Street Gun Violence as if It Were a Contagion
description: A program that started in Chicago treats street gun violence as an epidemic, hiring past offenders to disrupt transmission.
author: Tina Rosenberg
topic_tags: Gun Control, Crime,, Chicago, NYC
text: CHICAGO ó Gary Slutkin, an epidemiologist, has spent his life treating contagious diseases: cholera, tuberculosis, H.I.V. ó and for the last 23 years, violence. Yes, violence. A disease is a condition with identifiable symptoms that causes sickness or death. That describes violence. And we know it spreads itself. There is overwhelming evidence that hurt people hurt other people. Children who grow up in poverty and misery do not commit violence ó unless they experienced it. If they were chronically exposed to violence as a child, they are more than 31 times more likely than other people to behave violently themselves. Dr. Slutkinís work taught him that to control an epidemic, people must abandon practices that spread disease. Changing community norms is a far more effective method than simply giving people information. ìThe best predictor of condom use is whether people think their friends use condoms,î he said. Thatís why trusted community members with some training are so effective. ìOutsiders can guide and train and provide people with skills,î said Dr. Slutkin. ìBut all epidemics are always worked from the inside out.î In 1995, he began work on an idea that is now at the core of a program called Cure Violence, which is part of the University of Illinois at Chicago School of Public Health. (The program used to be called CeaseFire, and still is in many places. Thatís confusing, as Ceasefire is also the name of a completely different violence-prevention program.) Cure Violence didnít invent the idea of street work to reduce crime; Chicago was using it in the 1940s, according to Andrew Papachristos, a prominent scholar of gun violence who now teaches at Northwestern. ìBut Cure Violence took it to another level,î Professor Papachristos said. ìIt professionalized street work and put it into public health.î Demeatreas Whatley is 46 and a part-time college student who ultimately wants to get a doctorate in public health. He also works for Cure Violence at one of its 10 Chicago sites ó a new storefront office in the Grand Crossing neighborhood on Chicagoís South Side, one of the cityís most violent places. When Mr. Whatley got out of prison in 2008, after serving 17 years for aggravated discharge of a firearm, one of the first things he did was to volunteer for Cure Violence. ìI wanted my block safe,î he said. The use of a gun to settle even petty disputes is not at all the norm in poor communities of color. It is the norm among a very small group of individuals ó mostly young, mostly men. For this group, people like Mr. Whatley are the most credible messengers. For nine years he worked as a ìviolence interrupter,î which meant detecting imminent violence, talking people out of shooting and mediating the kind of disputes that often lead to chains of retaliatory shootings. I asked Mr. Whatley to describe an intervention. ìSay thereís a fight,î he said. ìThe guy who loses goes to get a gun. Youíve got to calm him down and let him save face. I tell him: ëI lost plenty of fights. At the end of the day, youíre a stand-up guy because you fought. Itís the coward who goes to get the gun.íî Mr. Whatley said people forget about consequences in a heated moment, especially if friends are egging them on. So he reminds them. ìIf you shoot this guy, youíll be the prime suspect,î he would say. ìDo you want to lose at least eight years of your life because you lost a fight? Why donít you leave it to us?î And he and his colleagues would then find someone trusted by the other party, who could persuade the man to drop the beef and stay away. A few months ago, Mr. Whatley began supervising Cure Violenceís new site in Grand Crossing. His group has 11 violence interrupters and four outreach workers. The outreach workersí job is to get the clients help, from finding a slot in drug or alcohol rehab to helping a client pack up and move in the middle of the night. All 15 staff members are from the neighborhood. Many said they had been doing this work informally before they were hired. ìThereís a sense of urgency to right your wrongs,î said Jessie Davis, a violence interrupter. Shooting is a relatively easy behavior to change, Dr. Slutkin said. People addicted to smoking want to smoke. Risk-takers want to have risky sex. But generally speaking, tough street guys brandishing guns donít want to shoot. John Hardy, a former violence interrupter who is now a senior program manager, said that such people often seek out an interrupter so they can back away from a public threat without losing face. ìConsciously or unconsciously, they want someone to talk them down,î he said. Every Tuesday afternoon, the Grand Crossing staff meets to review the past week. In late April, Mr. Whatley sat at the front of the room with his laptop, on which he tracks the groupís work. The staff members, all wearing black Cure Violence hoodies or orange windbreakers, went over the weekís incidents of violence, discussed particularly hot corners or blocks and described mediations they had conducted. One interrupter said that a fight had erupted over a video posted on social media, a huge generator of beefs. The interrupter persuaded the postís originator to agree to take down the video, and got the person who felt disrespected to leave it at that. ìGood work,î Mr. Whatley told the group. ìWeíre going to close out April pretty strong.î The staff had conducted 18 mediations ó double the number in March. In the past month there was not a single gang-related homicide in the Cure Violence siteís territory, he announced. Shootings are an after-school and nighttime activity, so thatís when the staff members go out on the beat. They go in groups of five to seven people for safety. After the meeting, one group drove a few blocks and parked in the lot of a Foodtown grocery store. They stood on the sidewalk, up against a chain-link fence. The location was strategic, just down the block from two schools about to let children out for the day. The staff gave out postcards with messages seeking an end to violence. Four young men who are clients of the program wandered over, and the staff invited them to a monthly cookout the group was holding on the weekend. They traded stories about their children. An outreach worker told them about a job-training program at Chicagoís power company. A middle-aged man pulled into the parking lot and got out of his car. When he was young, he had been involved in violence. Now the man is a key source of intelligence for Cure Violence, said an outreach worker named Chrisse. ìHe helps us stay on top of things,î Chrisse said. ìHe gives me a heads-up if itís clear or there are guys lying in wait. Iíll get a text: ëNot a good day, Chrisse.íî Cure Violence is working in a dozen cities in Latin America, and several in Africa and the Middle East. Iraqis are using the model to defuse sectarian conflicts, and Moroccans to try to reduce violent extremism. When the program began in San Pedro Sula, Honduras, the city was the most violent on earth, with a murder rate 31 times the global average. Thatís no longer the case. In the first five Cure Violence zones, which had 89 shootings from January to May in 2014, there were only five in the same period of 2015, and several zones went more than a year without a single shooting. In the United States, many Cure Violence neighborhoods have similarly gone on long streaks without a shooting ó some a year or two. Other places donít manage a streak but do have remarkable drops in violence nevertheless. (There are also some mixed results: In Baltimore a decade ago, the program reduced violence over all, but in one neighborhood murders rose, because of an intense gang war.) Cure Violence operates in 21 United States cities, but it will always be most linked to its hometown, Chicago, which, sadly, in recent years has been Americaís murder capital. The cityís homicide rate has swung wildly: In 2003, homicides dropped by 25 percent. Between 2014 and 2016, they rose by 87 percent. And last year, they abruptly dropped again. Chicagoís spike a couple years ago can be attributed to several factors: a breakdown of police-community relations after the shooting of Laquan McDonald by a policeman in 2014, increased access to already highly accessible guns, and Illinoisís multiyear inability to pass a budget, which has resulted in deep cuts to social programs such as summer jobs, after-school programs and drug treatment. Those cuts have also affected Cure Violence: At times itís been in 15 Chicago neighborhoods, and at times virtually shut down. Chicagoís conservative police department hasnít protected the program. The department has never been truly comfortable with the public health idea, or with ceding influence to former criminals. (The program is good for interrupters ó ìit keeps us from relapsing,î said Mr. Whatley. But some do fall back into violence; about a dozen in the city have been charged with serious crimes in the past decade.) But thereís something curious about the ups and downs of Chicagoís homicide rate: Every turning point in the graph coincides with a change in Cure Violenceís scope. When it expanded, murder started to fall. When the program was cut, killings started to jump. None of that is scientific evidence, Professor Papachristos, the sociologist, pointed out in an interview. Seven years ago, he wrote a paper arguing (pdf, Page 1053) that the programís rapid spread had come despite a lack of rigorous evidence of success. But heís changed his mind, he said, citing several recent high-quality studies of Cure Violence, including research on New York City programs. They found that shootings declined much more in Cure Violence neighborhoods than in comparable areas without the program, as did social support for the use of guns to solve disputes. ìThe evaluations are positive but at times still mixed,î said Professor Papachristos. ìBut to think itís going to work with every gang and every neighborhood is Polyanna-ish. What needs to be done is: ëWhatís the combination that makes it work? What are the contexts in which it doesnít work?íî Some of the answers are obvious. Like any program, it doesnít work when it exists only as a skeleton. And efforts to copy Cure Violence have failed when organizers leave out key parts, such as the focus on the very highest-risk individuals. Violence interruption is the heart of the public health model. But itís not the only part. Next week, Iíll look at a new way street workers are trying to keep people alive.

headline: Frances Tiafoe Brings Fun Back to His Tennis, and Wins Follow
description: Tiafoe has long been considered one of the greatest prospects in his generation, but he had few achievements at the tour level until recently.
author: Ben Rothenberg
topic_tags: Tennis, Frances Tiafoe;Francis Tiafoe
text: CASCAIS, Portugal ‚<U+0080><U+0094> Frances Tiafoe looked ready for big-time success on the tennis court in this suburb of Lisbon ‚<U+0080><U+0094> until he was handed a celebratory Champagne bottle after the final on Sunday. Tiafoe, the runner-up, struggled to open it for several minutes before being helped by a tournament emcee. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Terrible, ‚<U+0080>ù Tiafoe said of his uncorking effort in an interview after the final. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>That needs work. That definitely needs work.‚<U+0080>ù Tiafoe, 20, was the youngest American man to reach a tour final on European clay in 28 years; Andre Agassi was two months younger when he reached the final of the 1990 French Open. Tiafoe fell, 6-4, 6-4, in the final of the Estoril Open to Jo√£o Sousa, who was the first Portuguese champion of a tour-level event in Portugal. Advertisement ‚<U+0080><U+009C>He‚<U+0080><U+0099>s a great guy and he‚<U+0080><U+0099>s improving a lot, ‚<U+0080>ù Sousa, 29, said of Tiafoe. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>He‚<U+0080><U+0099>s going to reach a lot of finals.‚<U+0080>ù Playing in front of a crowd vociferously and unanimously supporting his opponent was a new experience that ‚<U+0080><U+009C>didn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t feel great, ‚<U+0080>ù Tiafoe said, but there were plenty of positives to draw from the week. His semifinal performance, a 6-2, 6-3 thrashing of 11th-ranked Pablo Carre√±o Busta, was especially impressive. He also saved three match points in an opening-round victory over Tennys Sandgren. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It was an unbelievable week, and I hope I can just keep it going, ‚<U+0080>ù Tiafoe said. He has been considered one of the greatest prospects in his generation from a young age, but since turning pro in 2015 he has achieved relatively little at the tour level. He drew some attention for five-set losses in the first round of the United States Open against John Isner in 2016 and Roger Federer in 2017, but coming into the 2018 season, Tiafoe had won only nine of his 38 career main-draw matches on the ATP Tour. Only one of those victories came against a top-30 opponent. Tiafoe has 15 wins already this season, including six against top-30 opponents. He reached his first tour quarterfinal at the New York Open in February, and won his first title in Delray Beach, Fla., one week later. The surge seemed unlikely after the first month of the season. After going winless in two tournaments in Australia, Tiafoe returned home to Maryland downtrodden. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>You get a lot of things going in your head when you‚<U+0080><U+0099>re young and you haven‚<U+0080><U+0099>t really experienced it, ‚<U+0080>ù said Tiafoe, who is ranked 56th, a career-high. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It‚<U+0080><U+0099>s not like you can just turn it on.‚<U+0080>ù Going back to his roots allowed Tiafoe to reorient his mind-set and his season. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>I went home and really recuperated, ‚<U+0080>ù he said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Being back home is a great thing for me, being with my family, being with friends, being with people that have got your back no matter what. I had some deep talks with everyone, and their support meant a lot to me and it was something that I needed to hear.‚<U+0080>ù Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. Tiafoe decided to take part of his support system with him on the road full-time, adding his friend Zack Evenden, a 26-year-old Briton who played collegiate tennis at Florida A&M, to his traveling team to complement the work of his primary coach, Robby Ginepri. Advertisement ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It‚<U+0080><U+0099>s the best thing I‚<U+0080><U+0099>ve done, the best decision I‚<U+0080><U+0099>ve made, having him here, ‚<U+0080>ù Tiafoe said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>He keeps it real with me. He keeps the tour fun for me. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>At first we were just friends, but now he‚<U+0080><U+0099>s definitely taken on a coaching role under Robby. Robby comes to the bigger events, but Zack‚<U+0080><U+0099>s there each and every day. I credit all my success to him.‚<U+0080>ù That stability has helped ground Tiafoe, who admits he has ‚<U+0080><U+009C>had a lot of things going on‚<U+0080>ù previously, including changing agencies twice in his young career. Evenden said that a key for Tiafoe had been learning to take ‚<U+0080><U+009C>ownership‚<U+0080>ù of his tennis and measure his own gifts. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>He‚<U+0080><U+0099>s understanding that he doesn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t have to play his best tennis, highlight-reel tennis, in every match just to get wins, ‚<U+0080>ù Evenden said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>He‚<U+0080><U+0099>s starting to get comfortable on the tour and realized that he doesn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t have to have the match of his life just to get a win.‚<U+0080>ù Tiafoe‚<U+0080><U+0099>s comfort level on the tour shows itself in other ways. As he returned to the clubhouse after the final Sunday, Tiafoe turned up the stereo in a tournament car and gave a brief impromptu performance of OutKast‚<U+0080><U+0099>s ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The Way You Move‚<U+0080>ù to an audience of charmed volunteers. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It‚<U+0080><U+0099>s good to bring a different feel to tennis, and that‚<U+0080><U+0099>s what I feel like I bring, ‚<U+0080>ù he said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>I bring a different feel, a different swagger to tennis. I‚<U+0080><U+0099>m very easygoing, and very nonchalant, it looks like, when I‚<U+0080><U+0099>m out there ‚<U+0080><U+0094> I‚<U+0080><U+0099>ve got a little strut, and I like that. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>There‚<U+0080><U+0099>s no reason trying to fit in: Just be you, ‚<U+0080>ù he added. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>That was the biggest thing for me, just being me, and finding what works for me. I have that balance of having fun ‚<U+0080><U+0094> because I can need to have a ton of fun ‚<U+0080><U+0094> but also locking it in at times. I‚<U+0080><U+0099>ve found the perfect balance for me right now, and I‚<U+0080><U+0099>m being mature and growing as a tennis player.‚<U+0080>ù

headline: One by One, These Newborn Sisters Were Abandoned Near Berlin
description: The authorities are looking for a woman who gave birth to three girls abandoned on the outskirts of the city between 2015 and last year.
author: Christopher F. Schuetze, Palko Karasz
topic_tags: Child abandonment foundlings, Berlin, Police, Pregnancy
text: BERLIN ‚<U+0080><U+0094> DNA tests on three girls born between 2015 and last year and found abandoned on the outskirts of Berlin showed that they were sisters, the authorities confirmed on Tuesday. The police in Berlin are now appealing for information about the mother of Emma, Lilo and Hanna, who were all abandoned just hours after they were born around the city‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Pankow neighborhood. Police named the girls, who are now in foster care, local media reported. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It‚<U+0080><U+0099>s certainly the same mother, ‚<U+0080>ù said Michael Maass of the Berlin Police. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>And we are going on the assumption that it is probably the same father.‚<U+0080>ù All three girls, who were born about a year apart, were found around the Helios Clinic in Berlin-Buch, some 15 miles northeast of the capital‚<U+0080><U+0099>s center. But the way the umbilical cords were cut indicated that the births had not taken place in a hospital. The babies were probably delivered without medical help, according to police experts. Advertisement While the police are searching for the person responsible for abandoning the children and endangering their lives, they have made clear that the mother might be a victim herself. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>They are all girls ‚<U+0080><U+0094> maybe it was supposed to be a boy, ‚<U+0080>ù a Berlin police official, Uta R√∂sel, told RBB, the regional broadcaster. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Maybe the mother is in some kind of dependent relationship in which she is also being mistreated.‚<U+0080>ù At least five hospitals in Berlin offer places where mothers can leave unwanted newborns anonymously so they can receive immediate medical attention. The hospital in Buch is not one of them. But women in the city who want to give birth in a medical facility but not leave an official record of the birth can do so anonymously. The police gave scant information on the condition of the infants when they were found. In the first instance, the authorities published images of sullied baby clothes worn by the newborn, who was found lying on a pillow in a bus stop. Christopher F. Schuetze reported from Berlin and Palko Karasz from London.

headline: Why A.I. and Cryptocurrency Are Making One Type of Computer Chip Scarce
description: A microprocessor once found mostly in machines used for computer games turns out to have a role in both artificial intelligence systems and the mining of digital currencies.
author: Cade Metz
topic_tags: Computer Chip, Virtual Currency, Artificial intelligence, Bitcoin, Price, Data center, null, Bitmain, Ethereum, NVIDIA, Google
text: SAN FRANCISCO ‚<U+0080><U+0094> Two technology booms ‚<U+0080><U+0094> some people might call them frenzies ‚<U+0080><U+0094> are combining to turn a once-obscure type of microprocessor into a must-have but scarce commodity. Artificial intelligence systems, made by companies ranging in size from Google to the Chinese start-up Malong Technologies, rely heavily on a computer chip called a graphics processing unit, or G.P.U. The chips are also very useful in mining digital currencies like Ethereum, a Bitcoin alternative riding the same wave of hype as its more famous cousin. With people and companies involved in the two surging tech niches buying up the same chips, G.P.U.s have been in short supply over the past several months. Prices have increased by as much as 50 percent, according to some resellers and customers. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The chips are simply going out of stock, ‚<U+0080>ù said Matt Scott, a technologist from the United States who founded Malong after leaving Microsoft‚<U+0080><U+0099>s research lab in Beijing in 2014. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>And the problem is getting worse.‚<U+0080>ù Advertisement Malong, which is based in Shenzhen, China, is building a system that can analyze digital photos and learn to recognize objects. Doing so requires an enormous number of photos, and analyzing all these photos depends on the G.P.U. chip. When the company recently ordered new hardware from a supplier in China, the shipment was delayed by four weeks. And the price of the chips was about 15 percent higher than it had been six months earlier. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>We need the latest G.P.U.s to stay competitive, ‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Scott said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>There is a tangible impact to our research work.‚<U+0080>ù But he did not blame the shortage on other A.I. specialists. He blamed it on cryptocurrency miners. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>We have never had this problem before, ‚<U+0080>ù he said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It was only when crypto got hot that we saw a significant slowdown in our ability to get G.P.U.s.‚<U+0080>ù G.P.U.s were originally designed to render graphics for computer games and other software. In recent years, they have become an essential tool in the creation of artificial intelligence. Almost every A.I. company relies on the chips. Like Malong, those companies build what are called neural networks, complex algorithms that learn tasks by analyzing vast amounts of data. Large numbers of G.P.U.s, which consume relatively little electrical power and can be packed into a small space, can process the huge amounts of math required by neural networks more efficiently than standard chips. Speculators in digital currency are snapping up G.P.U.s for a very different purpose. After setting up machines that help run the large computer networks that manage Ethereum and other Bitcoin alternatives, people and businesses can receive payment in the form of newly created digital coins. G.P.U.s are also efficient for processing the math required for this digital mining. Crypto miners bought 3 million G.P.U. boards ‚<U+0080><U+0094> flat panels that can be added to personal and other computers ‚<U+0080><U+0094> worth $776 million last year, said Joe Peddie, a researcher who has tracked sales of the chips for decades. Advertisement That may not sound like a lot in an overall market worth more than $15 billion, but the combination of A.I. builders and crypto miners ‚<U+0080><U+0094> not to mention gamers ‚<U+0080><U+0094> has squeezed the G.P.U. supply. Things have gotten so tight that resellers for Nvidia, the Silicon Valley chip maker that produces 70 percent of the G. P.U. boards, often restrict how many a company can buy each day. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It is a tough moment. We could do more if we had more of these‚<U+0080>ù chips in our data centers, said Kevin Scott, Microsoft‚<U+0080><U+0099>s chief technology officer. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>There are real products that could be getting better right now for real users. This is not a theoretical exercise.‚<U+0080>ù Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. AMD, another G.P.U. supplier, and other companies, say that some of current shortage is a result of a limited worldwide supply of other components on G.P.U. boards, and they note that retail prices have begun to stabilize. But in March, at his company‚<U+0080><U+0099>s annual chip conference in Silicon Valley, Nvidia‚<U+0080><U+0099>s chief executive, Jen-Hsun Huang, indicated that the company still could not produce the chips fast enough. This has created an opportunity for numerous other chip makers. A company called Bitmain, for instance, has released a new chip specifically for mining Ethereum coins. Google has built its own chip for work on A.I. and is giving other companies access to it through a cloud computing service. Last month, Facebook indicated in a series of online job postings that it, too, was working to build a chip just for A.I. Dozens of other companies are designing similar chips that take the already specialized G.P.U. into smaller niches, and more companies producing chips means a greater supply and lower prices. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>You want this not just for economic reasons, but for supply chain stability, ‚<U+0080>ù said Mr. Scott of Microsoft. The market will not diversify overnight. Matthew Zeiler, the chief executive and founder of a computer-vision start-up in New York, said the prices of some of the G.P.U. boards that the company uses have risen more than 40 percent since last year. Mr. Zeiler believes that Nvidia will be very hard to unseat. Many companies will stick with the company‚<U+0080><U+0099>s technology because that is what they are familiar with, and because the G.P.U. boards it provides can do more than one thing. Kevin Zhang, the founder of ABC Consulting, has bought thousands of G.P.U.s for mining various digital currencies. He said that a chip just for, say, mining Ethereum was not necessarily an attractive option for miners. It cannot be used to mine other currencies, and the groups that run systems like Ethereum often change the underlying technology, which can make dedicated chips useless. Advertisement Interest in digital currency mining could cool, of course. But the A.I. and gaming markets will continue to grow. Mr. Zeiller said that his company had recently bought new G.P.U.s for its data center in New Jersey, but could not install them for more than a month because the computer racks needed to house the chips were in short supply as a result of the same market pressures. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The demand, ‚<U+0080>ù he said, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>is definitely crazy.‚<U+0080>ù Follow Cade Metz on Twitter: @CadeMetz

headline: The Woman at the Center of Gov. Eric Greitens‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Criminal Trial
description: When an invasion of privacy case against Missouri‚<U+0080><U+0099>s governor opens, one woman‚<U+0080><U+0099>s account of what happened will be essential.
author: Julie Bosman
topic_tags: Eric Greitens, Missouri, Adultery
text: As Gov. Eric Greitens of Missouri faces a criminal trial next week for a felony charge of invasion of privacy, he has sought to prevent the woman at the center of the case from testifying in open court. A judge in St. Louis denied the request on Monday, saying that he would not bar her testimony ‚<U+0080><U+0094> an account that could be crucial to prosecutors‚<U+0080><U+0099> contention that Mr. Greitens took an explicit photograph of the woman without her consent. Mr. Greitens‚<U+0080><U+0099>s legal and political fate could hinge on the account from the woman, who had sexual encounters with Mr. Greitens in 2015, before he was governor. So far, she has remained anonymous, though she has revealed details of her relationship with Mr. Greitens under oath to legislators in Missouri. Here is what we know about the woman, who is identified in court filings only by her initials, K.S. K.S. is a resident of the St. Louis area who works as a hairdresser. A mother of two, she was separated from her husband when she had her first sexual encounter with the governor. She is now divorced. Advertisement She first met Mr. Greitens in 2013 when he began visiting her salon and became a regular client. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>I thought he was this perfect guy, ‚<U+0080>ù she told a legislative committee in March. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>I knew that he was an author, I knew he was a motivational speaker, I knew he was a Navy SEAL.‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Greitens, who is married, has been unambiguous about his relationship with K.S.: They had a brief affair before he was governor, and it came to an end. K.S. has described it as something more complicated. In her testimony to lawmakers in March, K.S. described her initial relationship with Mr. Greitens as friendly and flirty. In March 2015, it took a sexual turn when Mr. Greitens moved his hand ‚<U+0080><U+009C>all the way up‚<U+0080>ù between her legs during his hair appointment, she told the committee. They met at his home at his urging, an encounter that began strangely ‚<U+0080><U+0094> when she walked into his house, he searched her purse, patted her down and looked outside to make sure her arrival had not been noticed. In her account, she said they went to the basement, where Mr. Greitens took her photo while she was undressed and blindfolded, before threatening to make sure the photograph would be ‚<U+0080><U+009C>everywhere‚<U+0080>ù if she ever mentioned his name to anyone. She felt the only way she could leave his home was if she performed oral sex, she told the House investigative committee. The two had several more sexual encounters over a period of months. Then in October 2015, she told Mr. Greitens she didn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t want to see him or hear from him again, and he complied. He continued his Republican bid for governor, touting his background as a military veteran, family man and philanthropist. In November 2016, Mr. Greitens won the race by six percentage points, handing Republicans, who already dominated the State House and Senate, full control of Jefferson City, the state capital. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. After the release of the legislative report detailing K.S.‚<U+0080><U+0099>s account, some lawmakers said they saw her as a victim of abuse. Advertisement The governor has denied threatening K.S. and says that they had a completely consensual relationship. He and his wife, Sheena, have ‚<U+0080><U+009C>emerged stronger‚<U+0080>ù after the affair, the two said in a joint statement in January. When Missouri lawmakers released their report about the woman‚<U+0080><U+0099>s testimony, Mr. Greitens sharply dismissed it, saying it contained ‚<U+0080><U+009C>explosive, hurtful allegations of coercion, violence, and assault, ‚<U+0080>ù which he flatly denied. He said that the claims would be refuted by depositions and other evidence once he was able to have his case heard in court. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>A court of law and a jury of my peers will let every person in Missouri know the truth and prove my innocence, ‚<U+0080>ù he said. For more than two years, the relationship remained out of public view. In December 2017, K.S.‚<U+0080><U+0099>s ex-husband approached media outlets in St. Louis with a recording he had made ‚<U+0080><U+0094> in secret ‚<U+0080><U+0094> of a conversation he and K.S. had about Mr. Greitens. On the tape, K.S. tearfully admitted the affair and told her then-husband that Mr. Greitens had photographed and threatened to blackmail her. Since then, she has said that she was horrified by her ex-husband‚<U+0080><U+0099>s actions and struggled to keep the story from being publicized.
