headline: Japan Seeks Its Economic Mojo in the Stuff That Makes the Stuff
description: Precision parts and behind-the-scenes technology could play a major role in the countryës effort to shake itself out of its slow-growth doldrums.
author: Michael Schuman
topic_tags: Japan, Economy, Manufacturing, Electronics
text: TOKYO ó There is absolutely nothing sexy about bellows. But they just might be the future of Japan. The cylindrical metal products made by Irie Koken Company more resemble Slinkys on steroids than the gee-whiz gadgetry for which Japan was once famous, like Sonyís Walkman, Nintendoís Game Boy and Toyotaís Prius. But they perform the crucial if underappreciated task of helping makers of semiconductors and LCD panels keep their products clean and working. ìThe technology used in making these products is very difficult,î said Norihiro Irie, Irie Kokenís president. ìNot many companies are able to do it.î Some economists and businesspeople believe that slow-growth Japan may be forging a new, critical role in the global economy: making the stuff that makes the stuff for todayís digital revolution. Japan has become an essential supplier of robotics that power assembly lines; electronic systems for cars; circuit boards, sensors and other parts in your smartphone; and a host of other technical components and hardware hidden from the consumerís eye. Japan is moving toward ìan entirely different strategy, where other countries cannot compete,î said Ryoji Musha, president of the economic analysis outfit Musha Research in Tokyo. ìGoing forward, Japan will show a remarkable emergence as one of the locomotives of the global economy.î That would be good news for everyone. Japan remains the worldís third-largest economy, behind only the United States and China. A stronger Japan would offer a badly needed pillar to support global growth and serve as a counterweight to rising Chinese political and economic clout. Bellows and the many other Japanese products like them have already helped buoy the countryís growth. Over the past two years, the economy has experienced the longest continuous expansion since the 1980s. Last yearís 1.7 percent growth rate was the fastest since 2013. Sustaining it wonít be easy. Japanese companies will have to strive to keep their quality edge over low-cost China, which has caught up with Japan in making things like televisions and appliances, as well as over rivals including the United States, South Korea and Taiwan. Japanís image on quality has been hit recently by a number of scandals. More broadly, Japanese society is still shrinking, aging and deeply skeptical of immigrants. That will make it difficult for companies to find enough skilled workers and will put pressure on the countryís leaders to keep its education system up to the task. Many of Japanís biggest players have to look beyond the countryís borders in their quest for growth. Thedeclining population helped drive Takeda Pharmaceuticalís deal on Tuesday for Shire ó the largest-ever overseas acquisition by a Japanese company. ìThe undertow pulling at the dynamics of growth is the main limit to what Japan can do on a sustained basis,î said Kenneth Courtis, chairman of the finance firm Starfort Investment Holdings. Though Japan has some competitive companies that will continue to excel, he said, ìI donít know if that changes the overall equation.î Japan also had several false starts over the past quarter-century, only to stumble back into the doldrums. If this time is different, one big reason will be companies like Irie Koken. Mr. Irie said business had not been this good since he took over as the companyís president 19 years ago. Sales more than doubled in its last fiscal year. ìWe canít catch up with all our orders,î Mr. Irie said. With I.T. becoming more critical to just about every sector and factories looking to improve efficiency, greater demand is expected for robots, chips and other high-tech products ó and the made-in-Japan parts and machines needed to manufacture them. ìEven if there is a recession, I donít see it changing speed right now,î said Rosen Diankov, chief technology officer at the robotics firm Mujin Inc. Mr. Diankov, an American robotics specialist, cofounded Mujin in 2011 with Japanís Issei Takino, a former cutting-tool sales manager, to produce devices that control industrial robots. Its headquarters in a refurbished warehouse in east Tokyo has the hipster vibe of a garage start-up, with offices and workshops cluttered with equipment. Such entrepreneurial companies are all too rare in Japan, where venture capital and risk-taking are scarce compared with the United States or China. But Mujinís founders believe Japan is leading the way in automation, and they wanted to be part of the action. ìWe could have opened our company in Silicon Valley,î said Mr. Takino, who is the firmís chief executive officer. ìOne of the good things about being in Japan is that it is very easy to find a customer.î Mujinís technology can appear retro at first glance. One hand-held remote looks as if it belongs with a 1990s video game console. But Mujin says its advanced components make robots more efficient and easier to use, and are hard for competitors to recreate. The sheer complexity of these Japanese specialties may help the economy maintain a competitive edge. Unlike the TVs, CD players and other consumer electronics that drove Japanís past boom, Mujinís controllers and Irie Kokenís bellows are much harder for manufacturers in China and elsewhere to replicate. When the Beijing-based online retailer JD.com wanted to automate an unmanned warehouse in China, it turned to Mujin. Some of Japanís big corporations are heading in the same direction. The electronics giant Panasonic was once synonymous with TV sets and videorecorders. But over the past six years, it has drastically downsized its consumer businesses ó it no longer sells televisions in the United States at all ó and shifted into industrial electronics, including the batteries for Tesla roadsters and sensors and cameras for automobiles. ìIt is very important to position ourselves wisely,î said Yasuyuki Higuchi, chief executive of Panasonicís connected solutions unit. ìOtherwise, we cannot be competitive.î However, even the most competitive sectors arenít immune from Japanís problems. Severe labor shortages are already plaguing businesses, said Marcel Thieliant, senior Japan economist at the research firm Capital Economics, who added that the country isnít welcoming nearly enough foreigners to offset the impact. ìThe demographic headwinds will continue to resist,î said Mr. Thieliant, who estimates that Japanís current spate of growth has already ended. ìIf you donít get more immigrants in, you eventually hit a wall.î Mr. Irie has struggled to find the workers he needs to fill the deluge of new orders. His customers now have to wait twice as long as usual for their bellows ó up to five months. ìThe economy is very good, so good workers are being taken by other companies,î he complained. The shortage has prodded management to invent new ways to attract talent. Mujin employs a chef to cook lunch for the staff every day. Mr. Irie in recent years has taken all of his employees on a Hawaii vacation and renovated the companyís offices. ìThe older employees asked: ëWhy do you have to spend money to make things stylish?íî Mr. Irie said. ìThe image of manufacturing may not be very nice. We want to change it.î He remains optimistic, too. He plans to expand the capacity of his factory in Japan over the next few years, possibly making the firmís largest-ever investment. ìWe are riding a wave,î he said. ìWe can be on this wave because we have something special.î

headline: John Skipper, Who Abruptly Left ESPN, Has a New Job
description: The former chief executive of ESPN, who resigned in December after revealing a substance abuse problem, has landed at Perform Group.
author: Kevin Draper
topic_tags: Appointments and Executive Changes, ESPN, Perform Group, John Skipper
text: John Skipper, the former president of ESPN, has been hired as the executive chairman of the sports media company Perform Group, according to a release from the company. Less than six months after his resignation from ESPN, Skipper will soon be competing against his former longtime employer. Skipper was with ESPN for over 20 years and its president for six years. He resigned in December, citing a ìsubstance addiction.î In March, he revealed to The Hollywood Reporter that heíd had a cocaine problem and received unspecified ìtreatment,î and that his resignation followed an extortion attempt by somebody he had bought drugs from. The Perform Group is based in London, with offices around the world. It has a hand in just about every facet of the sports media business. Perform owns sports news properties, including The Sporting News and Goal in the United States; it has extensive investments in sports data, including Opta, a leader in statistical analysis for soccer; it also partners with leagues, including the N.F.L., to sell sports rights worldwide; and it owns DAZN, a streaming sports subscription service. The release announcing Skipperís appointment said that he would oversee all of Performís operations and strategy, but both his statement and that of Simon Denyer, the founder and chief executive of Perform, implied that Skipper would be focusing on DAZN. ìPerform Groupís platform and expertise, coupled with its success in launching subscription services in Germany, Japan and Canada provides a model we intend to replicate around the world,î Skipper said. DAZN, pronounced ìDa Zone,î has been hyperbolically called the Netflix of Sports. Available in five countries ó Germany, Austria, Switzerland, Japan and Canada ó it gives sports fans access to thousands of live sports events for a monthly subscription fee, usually around $20. In Japan, DAZN cornered much of the live sports market, acquiring rights to show the J.League games from 11 of the 12 Nipon Professional Baseball teams, most of the popular soccer leagues worldwide, the N.F.L. and the N.B.A. In Austria and Germany it only has Bundesliga highlight rights but will show the Champions League next year. DAZN launched in Canada last year with N.F.L. rights but has few other top-tier rights and the rollout was plagued by technical issues. Perform hasnít yet announced which countries will be next as part of that global rollout, but it is unlikely that Skipper will soon be engaged in bidding wars against his former company. Most American sports rights are unavailable to be bought for several years.

headline: 9/11 Planner, Tortured by C.I.A., Asks to Tell Senators About Gina Haspel
description: It isn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t known whether Ms. Haspel, nominated to lead the C.I.A., was involved in torturing Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who asked a military judge at Guant√°namo Bay for permission to share the information.
author: Charlie Savage
topic_tags: Torture, Terrorism, Gina Haspel, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, Detainees, US Politics, Classified Information, Interrogation,9/11;Sept 11, Military Tribunals, Waterboarding, Al Qaeda, CIA, Senate Intelligence Committee
text: WASHINGTON ‚<U+0080><U+0094> President Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s nomination of Gina Haspel to lead the C.I.A. has revived debate over the agency‚<U+0080><U+0099>s post-Sept. 11 interrogation program and still-murky questions about her involvement. Now, on the eve of her Senate confirmation hearing, a striking voice is trying to join that fray: Khalid Shaikh Mohammed. Mr. Mohammed, the principal architect of the Sept. 11 attacks, was captured in March 2003 and tortured by the C.I.A. This week, he asked a military judge at Guant√°namo Bay for permission to share six paragraphs of information about Ms. Haspel with the Senate Intelligence Committee. Ms. Haspel ran a black-site prison in Thailand where another high-level detainee was tortured in late 2002. But it is not known whether she was involved, directly or indirectly, in Mr. Mohammed‚<U+0080><U+0099>s torture. Mr. Mohammed was held in secret C.I.A. prisons in Afghanistan and Poland. In the weeks after his capture, an Intelligence Committee report said, Mr. Mohammed was subjected to the suffocation technique called waterboarding 183 times over 15 sessions, stripped naked, doused with water, slapped, slammed into a wall, given rectal rehydrations without medical need, shackled into painful stress positions and sleep-deprived for about a week by being forced to stand with his hands chained above his head. Advertisement While being subjected to that treatment, he made alarming confessions about purported terrorist plots ‚<U+0080><U+0094> like recruiting black Muslims in Montana to carry out attacks ‚<U+0080><U+0094> that he later retracted. They were apparently made up, the Senate report said. Ms. Haspel is scheduled to appear before the panel for a confirmation hearing on Wednesday, and several Democratic senators have called for the Trump administration to declassify more information about her involvement in the program to inform the debate about whether she is the right fit for the post. Mr. Mohammed‚<U+0080><U+0099>s request to provide unspecified information to the panel adds a new twist to that debate. It was described by one of his lawyers, Marine Lt. Col. Derek A. Poteet, who is helping to defend him from death-penalty charges before the military commissions system at the Guant√°namo Bay naval station. On Monday, Mr. Mohammed submitted a request to the judge overseeing pretrial hearings in that case, Army Col. James Pohl, Colonel Poteet said. While the file is not public on the commissions docket, Colonel Poteet said it consisted of an expedited motion for permission to provide the information to the committee about Ms. Haspel. The motion, Colonel Poteet said, included an attachment, titled ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Additional Facts, Law and Argument in Support, ‚<U+0080>ù containing ‚<U+0080><U+009C>six specific paragraphs of information‚<U+0080>ù from Mr. Mohammed that his client thinks the Intelligence Committee should know. After Mr. Mohammed raised the idea, his defense lawyers agreed that the information was important, Colonel Poteet said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>I am not able to describe the information, ‚<U+0080>ù he said. He added that it came from Mr. Mohammed himself, not from files turned over by the government to defense lawyers about the treatment of their client in C.I.A. custody. It is not clear whether Colonel Pohl would rule on the motion before Ms. Haspel‚<U+0080><U+0099>s hearing on Wednesday. Asked whether Ms. Haspel had any involvement in Mr. Mohammed‚<U+0080><U+0099>s detention or interrogation, Dean Boyd, a C.I.A. spokesman, said he was prohibited from commenting on her activities in 2003 given the sensitivity of her work. But, he said, on Monday the agency had delivered to the Senate a set of classified documents that describe her 33-year career ‚<U+0080><U+009C>including her time in C.I.A.‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Counterterrorism Center in the years after 9/11.‚<U+0080>ù The files are available to every senator, not just committee members, he said. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. Mr. Boyd also said the American people would get a chance to hear from Ms. Haspel directly at her confirmation hearing on Wednesday. Advertisement ‚<U+0080><U+009C>She has indicated to the senators she has met with, and will reaffirm tomorrow, her commitment never to restart such a C.I.A. detention and interrogation program, ‚<U+0080>ù he said on Tuesday. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>She remains fully committed to the U.S. laws and Army Field Manuals that govern interrogation ‚<U+0080><U+0094> the legal framework in place today.‚<U+0080>ù During the Bush administration, the Justice Department wrote secret memos approving C.I.A. torture techniques as purportedly lawful despite anti-torture laws. The department later withdrew those memos, and Congress enacted a law limiting interrogators to techniques listed in the Army Field Manual. The C.I.A. inspector general later found that agency interrogators sometimes exceeded the limits in the descriptions of techniques provided to the Justice Department for legal analysis. The Senate report also concluded that the C.I.A. misled the White House and other administration officials about its use of such techniques and portrayed them as more effective than they were. Ms. Haspel ran a black-site prison in Thailand in late 2002 while a detainee being held there, Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, who is accused of orchestrating Al Qaeda‚<U+0080><U+0099>s attack on the American destroyer Cole off the coast of Yemen in 2000, was subjected to torture techniques including waterboarding. She was also involved in destroying videotapes of interrogation sessions in 2005. The agency closed the Thailand prison in late 2002, and Ms. Haspel returned to the Counterterrorism Center outside Washington as a senior operations manager but continued to do temporary assignments overseas. But the details of what she was doing in 2003 are not public. This month, four Democratic senators on the Intelligence Committee ‚<U+0080><U+0094> Kamala D. Harris and Dianne Feinstein, both of California; Ron Wyden of Oregon; and Martin Heinrich of New Mexico ‚<U+0080><U+0094> wrote to Daniel Coats, the director of national intelligence, asking him to declassify all C.I.A. information related to Ms. Haspel‚<U+0080><U+0099>s involvement in the program before her hearing, since she, as acting director of the agency, has declined to do so on her own. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The American people deserve transparency regarding the background of a nominee who will be asked to represent them, and their values, around the world, ‚<U+0080>ù they wrote, adding, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Without making this information available to the American people, Ms. Haspel‚<U+0080><U+0099>s nomination cannot be fully and properly considered by the Senate.‚<U+0080>ù Follow Charlie Savage on Twitter: @charlie_savage.

headline: Kim Jong-un Returns to China, Bolstering Ties With Xi Jinping
description: The meeting between the North Korean and Chinese leaders came as China tries to regain a central role in the fast-moving diplomacy on the Korean Peninsula.
author: Jane Perlez, Gerry Mullany
topic_tags: US Foreign Policy, Yomiuri, Shinzo Abe, Moon Jae-in, Donald Trump, Dalian, North Korea
text: DALIAN, China ó President Xi Jinping of China met with Kim Jong-un, North Koreaís leader, on Tuesday, for the second time in two months, continuing a flurry of diplomacy over the Northís nuclear program. The meeting in the Chinese port city of Dalian near the North Korean border, came as China tries to regain a central role in the fast-moving diplomacy on the Korean Peninsula. It was announced on Chinaís state broadcaster, CCTV, which said that Mr. Kim arrived in Dalian on Monday and left on Tuesday. Xinhua, the official news agency, reported that Mr. Xi and Mr. Kim ìtook a stroll and attended a luncheon.î It added: ìIn a cordial and friendly atmosphere, the top leaders of the two parties and the two countries had an all-round and in-depth exchange of viewsî on relations between their two countries. The visit came just before Chinaís premier, Li Keqiang, was scheduled to go to Tokyo on Wednesday to meet President Moon Jae-in of South Korea and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan. The three are expected to discuss North Korean denuclearization among other issues. Chinese analysts speculated that Mr. Kim went to Dalian to ask Mr. Xi for sanctions relief. At the urging of the Trump administration, China grudgingly voted last year for United Nations sanctions that have hurt the Northís economy, draining its reserves of foreign currency. Mr. Kim recently met Mr. Moon, who is eager to help the North with economic aid. Their meeting also gave the North Korean leader new leverage with Mr. Xi. In essence, Mr. Kim can say that if China does not help ease the Northís economic pain, South Korea will. The two meetings between Mr. Xi and Mr. Kim represent a dramatic change from the frosty period, starting when Mr. Kim took power in 2011, when the two leaders refused to meet each other. In unusually positive language, Mr. Xi said that the North Korean leader had come ìto meet me again just after 40-odd daysî and ìat a crucial time when the Korean Peninsula situation is undergoing profound and complex changes,î according to Xinhua. Chinese state news outlets made pointed references to the fact that Mr. Kim had stayed overnight, making it a longer visit than the one last month between Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon of South Korea. Xinhua quoted Mr. Kim as saying he came to China again to ìstrengthen strategic communicationî with Mr. Xi. But Chinese analysts say the warmth between the two leaders should not be overstated, and that Mr. Kim retains his streak of independence. ìNorth Korea was never a vassal state,î said Shi Yinhong, a professor at Renmin University of China in Beijing. It is even less so now that the United States has agreed to deal with Mr. Kim, he said. By meeting Mr. Xi again, Mr. Kim would also most likely be trying to get Chinaís backing for his diplomatic overtures to President Trump, while assuring China, North Koreaís longtime ally, that it is not being left out of the diplomatic maneuvering with Washington. Mr. Trump and Mr. Kim are expected to meet later this month or in June. Hours after Mr. Kim flew home from Dalian, Mr. Trump tweeted that he would speak with Mr. Xi about the visit, as well as trade. Like Mr. Kimís visit to Beijing in March, his visit to Dalian was kept under wraps. But early Tuesday afternoon, the Japanese news service Kyodo reported that a plane from the North Korean carrier Air Koryo was at Dalianís airport. Chinese officials will be heading to Tokyo for meetings on Wednesday with South Korean and Japanese counterparts as part of the recent burst of diplomacy over North Korea. Japan, the host of the talks, has been pushing the United States to continue a tough line against Pyongyang. North Korean state news media on Tuesday criticized Japan for continuing to support tough sanctions against the North, with Rodong Sinmun, the countryís official newspaper, calling it ìtantamount to throwing cold water over easing tensions on the Korean Peninsula.î But Mr. Moon, who as South Koreaís leader has pushed for engagement with Pyongyang, urged Japan to consider normalizing ties with North Korea. ìI think dialogue between Japan and North Korea should be resumed,î Mr. Moon said in an interview Tuesday with the Japanese newspaper Yomiuri. ìIf Japan-North Korea relations are normalized, that would greatly contribute to peace and security in Northeast Asia beyond the Korean Peninsula,î he said in written answers to questions submitted by the newspaper. Dalian was also the site of a 2010 meeting between Mr. Kimís father, Kim Jong-il, and Mr. Li, who is now Chinaís premier. The city is a short flight or train ride from Pyongyang, making it a convenient venue for talks between the two nations. Mr. Kim, apparently not as fearful of flying as his father, traveled by plane. His father came to China by a slow-moving train.

headline: All Those Kitchen Gadgets, but a Sharp Knife Just Might Do
description: To industrial designers, the universe of kitchen tools is infinite. Egg timers and onion goggles aside, many tasks can be done with a blade.
author: Penelope Green
topic_tags: Cookware and bakeware, Interior Design, Kitchen
text: Berries are hot this year, Scott Goldsmith was saying on a recent rain-flecked Friday, brandishing a bright red plastic, wagon wheel-shaped gizmo called a PushBerry, which aims to hull and slice your strawberries in one go. Avocados, still hot, he added, gesturing at the Flexicado and the Avoquado ó two of the many slicers and pitters for sale in his store, all rendered in acid green plastic (designers of kitchen gadgets seem to go in for biomimicry). As for tenacious kale, this decadeís celebrity green, its grooming aids now include the Looseleaf and the Swiftstrip, otherwise known as kale leaf strippers, the solution to a problem you might not know you had. Mr. Goldsmith, 61, is the third-generation owner of S. Feldman Housewares ó a glittering bazaar on Manhattanís Upper East Side ó and an impresario of kitchen gadgetry. On this April morning, his shelves were bursting with esoterica like the billowy yellow silicone Food Pod (a combination steamer and colander that looks like vegetation imagined by the production designers of ìStar Trek,î $14.99); the SpreadTHAT titanium butter knife (ìItís pretty cool,î Mr. Goldsmith said. ìIt uses the heat of your hands. I donít eat much butter, but I donít discriminate,î $19.95); onion goggles ($19.95); and sequined aprons ($120) that were a big hit last Christmas. How do you wash the aprons? ìI have no idea,î he said. Mr. Goldsmithís long retail career spans decades of gadgetry ó including truffle shavers and cherry pitters, Salad Shooters and spiralizers ó and traces a history of ingenuity, optimism and sheer whimsy. If the invention of defoliating devices for cruciferous vegetables causes you to think the makers of kitchen gadgets have finally and collectively lost their minds, Mr. Goldsmith will remind you that his store has been in business since 1929. ìBetween you and me,î he said, ìmost of these things you can do with a knife.î To an industrial designer, the universe of possible kitchen tools is infinite. Very few objects would not benefit from a good rethinking, said Tucker Viemeister, a founder of Smart Design, among other companies, who has reimagined items as complex as a toaster, and as simple as a potato peeler. In 1990, when Smart Designís Oxo Good Grip peeler hit the market, with its fat, comfy rubber handle and fixed blade, it was a kind of revolution. ìOn the one hand, designers are really optimistic because they think they can make things better,î he said. ìOn the other hand, we think everything is wrong or broken.î In ìConsider the Fork: A History of How We Cook and Eatî (2012), Bee Wilson, the English food writer, explored how technology, social mores and food fashions have long collided to create a pageantry of gizmos. New technologies rendered entire categories obsolete; when stoves replaced the open hearth, the hasteners, spits, spit jacks and spit dogs that attended them vanished. Technology has altered the meal itself. After the Cuisinart, we were swimming in purÈes, a situation that Ms. Wilson said had contributed to the robust artisanal fare of today, prized because ìsomeoneís hand had been tired out making it.î As she wrote, ìthe birth of a new gadget often gives rise to zealous overuse, until the novelty wears off.î She continued, ìTo the woman who has just acquired an electric blender, the whole world looks like soup.î In terms of pure function, Ms. Wilson said recently, ìvery few new gadgets are any improvement on a sharp knife, a good source of heat and a dexterous pair of hands.î ìBut they reflect our obsessions and wants at any given time,î she added. ìThe Victorians had slaw cutters, which most of us today manage without, because shredded cabbage is not such a thing. The person who owns a kale stripper is confirming to themselves that kale is a big part of his or her life.î A decade ago, ìhalf the items for sale in cookware shops seemed to be cupcake-related,î she said. ìBut now we have moved on. Veganism seems to be where much of our cooking desire has moved, hence the incredible success of the spiralizer. When they started appearing a couple of years ago, I felt that spiralizers were destined for immediate obsolescence, but I was completely wrong. Maybe itís because of low-carb diets or maybe itís the rise of #plantbased on Instagram, but it turns out that the ability to turn a beet or zucchini into something resembling telephone wire speaks to more people than I ever knew.î Christopher Kimball, the determinedly skeptical cooking program host and co-founder of two food networks based in Boston, Americaís Test Kitchen and Milk Street, identified three categories of kitchen gadgets: Completely Idiotic Useless Objects, Things That Are Not Worth the Storage Space, and Things That Seem Practical But You Could Actually Do Better With a Knife. ìA well-designed tool is immensely valuable,î Mr. Kimball said. ìBut for the specialty items youíre only going to use once a month, how much more work is it not to use it?î Yet Mr. Kimball is not immune to the siren songs of some gizmos. A few years ago, at the International Home and Housewares Show, the food worldís annual gadgetfest held each March in Chicago, Mr. Kimball found himself unexpectedly moved by the BeepEgg, an adorable egg-shaped timer you boil with your eggs. When they have reached the desired degree of doneness ó soft, hard or in between ó BeepEgg plays a tune (like ìKilling Me Softlyî for soft boiled). Mr. Kimball also acknowledged having bought every iteration of egg poacher over the years, even though, as he said, ìat the end of the day, it actually isnít that hard to cook an egg.î In 2016, the last year for which sales figures are available, kitchen tools and accessories represented more than 13 percent of the total housewares pie, which was $87.1 billion, according to the International Housewares Association State of the Industry Report, a 6 percent increase over 2015. Howard Chiu, an engineer who worked in robotics and aerospace, quit his day job two and a half years ago when his invention was a finalist for the Chicago showís innovation award. Mr. Chiu is the man behind the SpreadTHAT, an idea that was inspired by watching his children flay their toast while trying to spread cold butter. Borrowing from his background, he took conducting tubes and coated them with titanium to make a device you could warm with the heat of your hands. SpreadTHAT sold well enough its first year that Mr. Chiu has built a brand around its principles (with products like a gravy warmer, HeatTHAT; an ice cream scooper, ScoopTHAT; a meat thawer, ThawTHAT; and so forth). Ten years ago, Kraigh and Anna Stewart were designing in the furniture industry when they had their ìahaî moment. Ms. Stewart was in the middle of making her grandmotherís recipe for stuffed chicken breasts but didnít have any string or toothpicks. She wondered, Why isnít there something reusable you can tie food up with? ìSilicone had been around for ages,î Mr. Stewart said, ìbut we were the first to use it inside a pan.î They designed their Food Loops (packets of silicone trussing string) in psychedelic hues ó ìfuchsentaî is what they called their first iteration in hot pink ó so you would see them, and not toss them into the trash. ìWe sold half a million that first year, ì Mr. Stewart said. Like Mr. Chiu, the Stewarts quit their jobs and started a company, Fusionbrands, from that first product. The very particular looking Food Pod at Feldmanís is their handiwork (inspired by sea urchins, Mr. Stewart said) as is the EggXactPeel, a slim yellow plastic shell cracker and peeler that was a finalist for an innovation award at this yearís housewares show. Amanda Hesser, the food writer and co-founder and chief executive of Food52, the kitchen and home website, is continually evaluating products like these as her company develops its own for sale. She is an expert on obsolescence, a gimlet-eyed judge of what might have legs. But even Ms. Hesser has a misfit drawer in her kitchen, a mini-museum of the gadgetry of yore. Her particular affliction is melon ballers, including one model with a pea-size scoop (tantalizing for ìThe Borrowers,î perhaps, but otherwise useless). She also has an egg topper, which slices off the caps of eggs with Gallic precision, a butter curler and a shrimp deveiner. Despite a soft spot for such arcana, Ms. Hesser is not tempted by certain new trends. ìOnce you go down the road of having a kale leaf stripper,î she said, ìwhere do you draw the line? This is something we talk a lot about in our reviews. With kitchen manufacturers, there is this tendency to get so detailed and so tailored with their products, everyone would need 5,000-square-foot kitchens. Not to mention youíre missing out on the pleasure of ripping kale off its stem. Youíre letting the tool have all the fun.î Be wary of the rush to judgment, said Cheryl Mendelson, the essayist and novelist. ìOne personís useless gadget often turns out to be the meaning of anotherís life, and my pastry blender was pressed on me with fervent affection by someone who couldnít live without it. I gave it up after one try.î Ms. Mendelson is the author of ìHome Comforts: The Art and Science of Keeping House,î a passionate guide for the turn of the millennium that was a publishing sensation ó all 896 pages ó when it landed in 1999. The book was notable for its exhaustive rigor ó Ms. Mendelson, who is also a lawyer, teaches philosophy at Barnard College ó but it also showcased her abiding love of cooking. As it happened, she had purged her drawers recently, and some curious items remained: the aforementioned pastry blender, a cherry pitter, two garlic presses, a toast rack and a pasta noodle slicer. Ms. Mendelson said she had once imagined herself as the sort of person who deployed a toast rack at her family breakfast table and made her own pasta. It was these fantasies ó these ideas of selfhood ó that stayed their execution, she said. All of which reminded Ms. Mendelson of a William James joke. Apparently there are two. ìThis is the funny one,î she said. ìJames liked to say that if a philosophical theory was useless, if it didnít do any work in the philosophical sense, it brought to mind the story of the old Irishman who was being carried to a funeral in a broken sedan chair. Because the chair had no floor, the old man had to run along inside it. ëFaith,í the man says, ëif it werenít for the honor of the thing, I might as well walk.íî There is honor in a pasta slicer, Ms. Mendelson added, and so attention must be paid.

headline: Everything You (and John Oliver) Need to Know About Koala Chlamydia
description: To honor the comedian John Oliver, the actor Russell Crowe has donated a new medical ward in Australia to treat koalas with chlamydia.
author: Isabella Kwai
topic_tags: null, Chlamydia, Koalas, John Oliver, Australia
text: SYDNEY, Australia ‚<U+0080><U+0094> The comedian John Oliver, who made a name for himself as host of an HBO talk show, will now have his name in a slightly more embarrassing locale: outside a koala chlamydia clinic in Australia. While he is known for clever stunts ‚<U+0080><U+0094> Mr. Oliver recently published a children‚<U+0080><U+0099>s book about a gay bunny and started a church ‚<U+0080><U+0094> his latest prank may have backfired. After Mr. Oliver revealed that he had bought several items from the Australian actor Russell Crowe‚<U+0080><U+0099>s divorce auction, Mr. Crowe found ‚<U+0080><U+009C>a cool way‚<U+0080>ù to honor him. That ‚<U+0080><U+009C>cool way‚<U+0080>ù turned out to be a ward at a zoo, now called ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The John Oliver Koala Chlamydia Ward.‚<U+0080>ù Advertisement We‚<U+0080><U+0099>ll explain: Here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s what you ‚<U+0080><U+0094> and Mr. Oliver ‚<U+0080><U+0094> need to know about koala chlamydia. Sadly, yes. Some surveys of koala populations in Queensland have suggested at least half of wild koalas are infected with the disease ‚<U+0080><U+0094> possibly even more. Chlamydia causes conjunctivitis, which can lead to blindness, urinary tract infections and infections of the reproductive organs that can lead to female infertility. Researchers at the University of Sunshine Coast discovered in April that a retrovirus was further weakening koalas, making them even more susceptible to chlamydia. It‚<U+0080><U+0099>s not just chlamydia; dogs, loss of habitat, rapid urbanization and deaths from vehicles are also killing koalas. In some parts of Queensland, between 1994 and 2016, the koala population declined 80 percent. In 2012, the federal government classified koalas as ‚<U+0080><U+009C>vulnerable‚<U+0080>ù in the states of New South Wales and Queensland and in the Australian Capital Territory. The Australia Zoo estimates that 40,000 to 100,000 koalas ‚<U+0080><U+0094> a symbol of Australia‚<U+0080><U+0099>s unique wildlife ‚<U+0080><U+0094> remain in the wild. The usual way ‚<U+0080><U+0094> so stop visualizing it! Though transmitted through sex, koalas have little time for randy rooting, as the Australians call it, because they sleep about 20 hours a day. Damien Cave, our new Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. There are two main strains of bacteria that lead to chlamydia in the marsupials. The more common strain, Chlamydia pecorum, is responsible for most of the outbreak in Queensland and cannot be transmitted to humans. The second strain, C. pneumoniae, can infect humans if, say, an infected koala were to urinate on someone, though it‚<U+0080><U+0099>s unlikely. (Try sharing that tidbit next time a friend sends you a cute koala pic.) Advertisement Baby koalas, known as joeys, can also catch the disease from their mothers while nursing if they come into contact with infected feces. For humans, treatment of the disease involves an embarrassing trip to the doctor for antibiotics (and maybe a few angry texts). Antibiotics are also used to treat koalas, although they do not prevent re-infection and come with a host of unpleasant side effects. Research has shown that the treatment messes with the gut microbes that help them digest their leafy diet ‚<U+0080><U+0094> meaning they can starve. There have been successful trials of a vaccine to prevent infection in both healthy koalas and those in early stages of infection. Some of those experiments have taken place at the very wildlife hospital where Mr. Oliver‚<U+0080><U+0099>s name now adorns the wall. And don‚<U+0080><U+0099>t worry, the Australian government isn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t letting Mr. Oliver have all the credit: Just this Monday, the New South Wales government announced a 45 million Australian dollar plan to save the state‚<U+0080><U+0099>s koalas. (That‚<U+0080><U+0099>s almost $34 million.) Congratulations, John Oliver, on the koala chlamydia ward named after you https://t.co/p0V1yIIv2r pic.twitter.com/BD69bT3Sul Apart from his name forever memorialized with the words ‚<U+0080><U+009C>koala chlamydia, ‚<U+0080>ù a ward in Mr. Oliver‚<U+0080><U+0099>s honor was donated at the Australia Zoo Wildlife Hospital in Queensland. The ward will focus on treating and vaccinating koalas in that state. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Thanks to your auction, you are now saving literally thousands of koala lives, ‚<U+0080>ù said Bindi Irwin, daughter of the conservationist Steve Irwin, who died in 2006, in a video tweeted out by Mr. Crowe. The reward was all too much for Mr. Oliver, who joked Sunday on his show, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Last Week Tonight With John Oliver, ‚<U+0080>ù that he was so overcome by the accomplishment that he was done hosting it. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Don‚<U+0080><U+0099>t think of this as a sad occasion, because I leave you in total triumph at this point, ‚<U+0080>ù he said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>If you‚<U+0080><U+0099>ll excuse me, I‚<U+0080><U+0099>ve got a date with some very contagious koalas.‚<U+0080>ù Follow Isabella Kwai on Twitter: @bellakwai. Want more Australia coverage and discussion? Join us in our Facebook group, sign up for the weekly Australia Letter and start your day with the Australian Morning Briefing.

headline: On the Mattress for ‚<U+0080><U+0098>Sleep, ‚<U+0080><U+0099> an 8-Hour Lullaby
description: We were there for a performance of Max Richter‚<U+0080><U+0099>s all-night lullaby, scientifically engineered for relaxation.
author: Joshua Barone
topic_tags: Classical music, Max Richter, American Contemporary Music Ensemble, TriBeCa Manhattan
text: My first mistake was waking up early to get groceries. Then it was a long Friday at work, followed by a piano recital and finally a sprint downtown ‚<U+0080><U+0094> where, exhausted, I was in the worst possible shape to take in one more concert. Except that the performance was ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Sleep, ‚<U+0080>ù Max Richter‚<U+0080><U+0099>s eight-hour soundtrack engineered, with the help of scientific consultants, to provoke a relaxing night. By dozing off, I‚<U+0080><U+0099>d be doing my job. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Our lives are very data-saturated now, ‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Richter said in an interview last week. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>We‚<U+0080><U+0099>re always on our screens, and mostly we‚<U+0080><U+0099>re being sold stuff. It squeezes out a lot of richness of what we are.‚<U+0080>ù A calm, relaxing, very, very long work like his, he added, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>could act as a sort of protest song.‚<U+0080>ù But ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Sleep, ‚<U+0080>ù which unfolded on Friday and Saturday at Spring Studios in Manhattan after recently being released on streaming platforms for easy home consumption, was perhaps not the most robust protest against rampant materialism. For one thing, tickets cost $250. For another, the show ended up looking like a prolonged ad for Beautyrest, which provided the audience‚<U+0080><U+0099>s mattresses ‚<U+0080><U+0094> to be donated later to a charity for children who have trouble sleeping, Mr. Richter said ‚<U+0080><U+0094> and stamped its brand on everything: linens, sleep masks, swag bags. Advertisement The space, in a corner of TriBeCa bristling with new high-rises, was tricked out like an upscale disaster shelter. Marina Abramovic‚<U+0080><U+0099>s ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Goldberg, ‚<U+0080>ù a high-end sensory-deprivation treatment of Bach‚<U+0080><U+0099>s ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Goldberg‚<U+0080>ù Variations at the Park Avenue Armory a few years ago, came to mind. But before that Bach performance, all belongings ‚<U+0080><U+0094> even watches ‚<U+0080><U+0094> were shut into lockers so that audience members could be, in theory, fully ‚<U+0080><U+009C>present.‚<U+0080>ù At ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Sleep‚<U+0080>ù there were no such restrictions, and the data-saturated listeners, ostensibly approaching Mr. Richter‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Magic Mountain to briefly shun modernity, often had their phones out, busily documenting the night in text messages and posts on social media. Some people stood in the center aisle to pose for photos, with the band ‚<U+0080><U+0094> comprising Mr. Richter, members of the American Contemporary Music Ensemble and the soprano Grace Davidson ‚<U+0080><U+0094> visible behind them. Spring Studios‚<U+0080><U+0099> floor-to-ceiling windows offered the cityscape as an alluring backdrop for pajama-clad selfies. For some reason, water wasn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t available at the bar. I put away my notebook and tried to listen to ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Sleep‚<U+0080>ù as Mr. Richter intended. For the first half-hour, it was just him at the piano, playing a slow, pulsing lullaby. His rhythmic precision was admirable, given that his score was just stretches of whole notes; he played with the focus of a dyed-in-the-wool Minimalist. Composers from that movement were Mr. Richter‚<U+0080><U+0099>s earliest inspirations. As a boy in small-town Britain in the 1970s, he would get records from his family‚<U+0080><U+0099>s milkman, an artist who was tapped into the music of La Monte Young, Terry Riley and Philip Glass. He fell in love with Satie‚<U+0080><U+0099>s furniture music, and, eventually, the ambient soundscapes of Brian Eno. All of this factored into ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Sleep, ‚<U+0080>ù which was first released in 2015. But the piece is also a homage to Bach‚<U+0080><U+0099>s ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Goldberg‚<U+0080>ù Variations. (The two works have the same number of sections.) While aware that the piece‚<U+0080><U+0099>s origin story is apocryphal, Mr. Richter was intrigued that the ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Goldbergs‚<U+0080>ù were supposedly written for a count with insomnia. Bach, it needs be said, this ain‚<U+0080><U+0099>t. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Sleep‚<U+0080>ù is rife with the hallmarks of Mr. Richter‚<U+0080><U+0099>s style: a clarity that can seem like superficiality; an earnestness and emotionality that often come off as more ersatz and manipulative than personal. And it‚<U+0080><U+0099>s difficult to buy into an eight-hour exercise in mindfulness when, against Mr. Richter‚<U+0080><U+0099>s best intentions, it opened itself to being more of a social media sensation. Asked whether the performance could fall victim to the very thing it was trying to resist, Mr. Richter said, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It‚<U+0080><U+0099>s fraught with ironies.‚<U+0080>ù But he said he also hoped that the piece could help a community build toward ‚<U+0080><U+009C>a silence.‚<U+0080>ù Advertisement Silence did reign in the middle of the night, when the piece reached its enchanting apex. Around me people slept, or lay awake as if in a trance. The lofts and office towers of TriBeCa rested, too. There were no stars in the sky, but the lights twinkled in the choppy waves of the Hudson River. I fell asleep, and dreamed that someone was walking among the mattresses, handing out water. Around 5:30 in the morning, the sun began to rise, gradually filling the room with light as the ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Sleep‚<U+0080>ù orchestra played obvious music to match it: an increasingly loud, radiant major chord. If the earlier lullaby music had been purposefully low and mantralike, based on scientific research into what puts us to sleep, this gentle reveille also had an experimental basis: Higher frequencies wake us up. As people awoke, they grabbed their phones to capture the sunrise. A couple kissed and said good morning, as if at home and not surrounded by 100 strangers. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Sleep‚<U+0080>ù ended with a fade-out, immediately followed by the voice of a Beautyrest staff doctor, guiding the audience through meditation with the phlegmatic voice ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Saturday Night Live‚<U+0080>ù actors use to parody NPR. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Our motivation resets over the course of the symphony of the night, ‚<U+0080>ù she said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>What will you do today? What will you achieve today?‚<U+0080>ù It was difficult not to feel cynical as I walked out of the performance ‚<U+0080><U+0094> the break from being sold stuff that I‚<U+0080><U+0099>d been promised ‚<U+0080><U+0094> to have Beautyrest representatives handing me branded energy drinks. But then I met John Carl and Mary VandeRiet, two thirtysomething filmmakers. They had been awake most of the night, thinking it a waste to sleep through something so transcendental and peaceful. Ms. VandeRiet said she had never seen musicians onstage ‚<U+0080><U+009C>so entirely connected to the music.‚<U+0080>ù ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It was just perfect, ‚<U+0080>ù she said. Indeed, during the performance Mr. Carl had asked Ms. VandeRiet to marry him. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>We‚<U+0080><U+0099>ve listened to this album as we‚<U+0080><U+0099>ve slept, ‚<U+0080>ù he said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>We‚<U+0080><U+0099>ve listened to it at important moments in our lives. I had to do this.‚<U+0080>ù Follow Joshua Barone on Twitter: @joshbarone. A version of this article appears in print on May 8, 2018, on Page C7 of the New York edition with the headline: As the Band Played On (and On), Zzzzs. Order Reprints| Today's Paper|Subscribe

headline: ëMean Girlsí: Whatís New in Girl World and Whatís Out
description: Some things have changed since Tina Fey wrote the beloved movie, now a Broadway musical. But on Wednesdays, the Plastics still wear pink.
author: Carla Correa
topic_tags: Mean Girls, Mean Girls, Lindsay Lohan, Tina Fey, Theater, Movies
text: Get in, loser. Weíre about to relive the hellish days of high school through the eyes of our favorite queen bees and wannabes. ìMean Girlsî ó the 2004 film that starred Lindsay Lohan as Cady, a new student who tries to navigate the cliques of North Shore High ó has become one of the most quotable films, generating endless GIFs and memes. Now that itís on Broadway, you can sing some of the lines, too. The show was nominated for 12 Tony Awards, including best musical. Hereís your guide to North Shore in 2018. Tina Feyís adaptation for the musical (with music by Jeff Richmond and lyrics by Nell Benjamin) deviates from the movie, but everything is still fetch. Warning: Spoilers ahead. In 2004, Ms. Lohan, then a cog in the Disney machine, was an ìitî girl in Hollywood. Fans liked her because she seemed ó to use a line from Ms. Feyís book ó ìauthentic but not in a fake way.î Being an outsider is in. Janis and Damian take on the part of storytellers, and audiences seemed to like Cadyís ìart freakî friends in this role. Perhaps in 2018 we have less patience for a lead character who fails math to impress a boy. ìWhy are you so obsessed with me?î Regina, the queen bee of North Shore, asked of Janis in middle school, before spreading the rumor that her former best friend was a lesbian. This is why Janis wanted Cady to help her destroy Reginaís reputation. The musical has plenty of girl-power messaging, but it still hinges on the premise that middle school gossip about sexual orientation would define the social dynamics in a progressive community (ìMean Girlsî takes place in Evanston, Ill.). This might have been more plausible in 2004, when expressions of queer identities were less visible and socially acceptable. Yet Regina and others call Janis a ìspace dyke.î Ø\_(<U+30C4>)_/Ø Gretchen was described as being ìtotally richî in the film because her father was the inventor of Toaster Strudel. Gretchen didnít pass up the chance to tell Mr. Duvall, North Shoreís principal, that her father was behind the frozen pastry. Cady still supplies Regina with the fictional Swedish nutrition bars to sabotage her weight-loss goal. (Whatever, present-day Regina is getting cheese fries.) Regina reserved her spring fling dress at 1-3-5, an allusion to the mall retailer 5-7-9, but she couldnít zip it up. The saleswomanís advice: ìYou could try Sears.î The spring fling dress fits just fine. But Regina does wear sweats in the school cafeteria, prompting Gretchen to screech, ìYou canít sit with us!î He was the boy who got four candy cane grams and spurred a thousand memes. But those memes spelled his name wrong. Thatís right, Coccoís name includes two Cís. It always has. But his name wasnít in the filmís credits, so meme-makers guessed the spelling. They guessed wrong. Regina tricked Cady into trash-talking Gretchen while Gretchen was on the line. Cady tricked Regina into trash-talking Gretchen and Karen on a group call. All four used landline telephones. Who uses a landline? LED screens show posts related to what the girls say and do. The limit does not exist! Karen told Cady: ìIím kind of psychic. I have a fifth sense. Itís like I have ESPN or something.î In 2004, many eyes were glued to ESPN. In an era of #fakenews, many eyes are glued to Twitter. Regina jokes that President Trump has blocked her on the site. ìCoach Carr, step away from the underage girls!î The same coach, who said, ìDonít have sex because you will get pregnant and die,î was accused of having inappropriate relationships with two students. References to pedophilia are out in the age of #MeToo. The Burn Book does reveal that Cadyís crush, Aaron, uses a fake address to attend North Shore, so heís expelled. He doesnít even go there anymore! The big questions, though, are why a Burn Book exists in 2018, and why Regina would photocopy its contents instead of posting pages on Instagram. The Plastics danced to the Christmas tune at the winter talent show. Gretchen accidentally kicked the portable CD player, causing the song to skip. Cady saved the day by leading a singalong. The change was a creative decision. And now a boombox doesnít malfunction. (Do boomboxes, like, exist anymore?) Instead, Reginaís skirt pops off, and she is shamed on social media. In the film, Aaron asked Cady what day it is. ìItís October Third,î she said. In the musical, Aaron asks Cady what day it is. ìItís October Third,î she says.

headline: As Melania Trump Faces Plagiarism Claims, Her Staff Lashes Out at News Media
description: A booklet with the branding of her ìBe Bestî initiative was first published by the Federal Trade Commission during the Obama era, setting off a storm of accusations.
author: Katie Rogers
topic_tags: Melania Trump, Plagiarism, Twitter, Speeches, First Ladies, FTC
text: WASHINGTON ó Melania Trumpís rollout this week of her ìBe Bestî initiative focusing on children was intended to give the first lady an agenda all her own. Instead, it revived accusations that Mrs. Trumpís ideas were really coming from somewhere else. Observers on Twitter quickly pointed out that one of the primary materials with ìBe Bestî branding, a booklet on social media guidelines called ìTalking With Kids About Being Online,î had been circulated by the Federal Trade Commission during the Obama era. As the story spread, Mrs. Trumpís communications director published an extraordinary statement on Tuesday that admonished the news media for reporting on the plagiarism claims. ìOur office will continue to focus on helping children, and I encourage members of the media to attempt to Be Best in their own professions,î the communications director, Stephanie Grisham, wrote, ìand focus on some of the children and programs Mrs. Trump highlighted in her remarks yesterday.î Before the official ìBe Bestî rollout on Monday, aides had been upfront to reporters when asked about the fact that Mrs. Trumpís office was repackaging items, including the Federal Trade Commission booklet, from other programs. Among program materials distributed to reporters covering the event was an initiative by the National Safety Council intended to encourage people to talk to their doctors about opioid abuse. Mrs. Trumpís staff plans to continue to solicit ideas for the initiative, which focuses on opioid abuse, social media pressures and mental health issues among young people, from places the first lady has visited. Those include a West Virginia clinic that treats infants born with opioid addiction and a Michigan school where students participate in a program to stress the importance of emotional intelligence and kindness. But critics did not buy the defense. Mrs. Trump enjoys higher popularity ratings than her husband, but she has been accused of plagiarism before. In 2016, a large part of a speech she delivered at the Republican convention appeared to be taken from remarks Michelle Obama, her immediate predecessor, delivered in 2008. On Monday, observers also noted that Mrs. Obama had delivered remarks in 2016 urging men to ìbe better.î Like her husband, Mrs. Trump is also viewed by many as having baggage related to the Obamas, stemming back to jabs she took at President Barack Obama while her husband was promoting the conspiracy theory that Mr. Obama was not an American citizen: ìItís not only Donald who wants to seeî Mr. Obamaís birth certificate, Mrs. Trump said during a 2011 interview. ìItís American people who voted for him and who didnít vote for him.î Mr. Obama eventually released his long-form birth certificate. The East Wing is known to lash out when faced with coverage the first lady views as unfair: In October, Mrs. Trump directed her office to release a scorching statement criticizing President Trumpís first wife, Ivana, for jokingly referring to herself as the first lady. But East Wing aides who had worked to execute a tightly scripted and controlled kickoff ó and who are particularly sensitive when observers draw comparisons to the Obamas ó had not anticipated the negative reaction to the booklet. Different versions of it have circulated since at least 2009, and the booklet is meant to be distributed, as the Federal Trade Commission noted in its own news release on Monday: ìWeíre excited that the first lady is sharing this important information with families across the country,î an agency official, Nat Wood, wrote in a statement. In the version the East Wing distributed on Monday, the only original part appeared to be a brief statement signed by Mrs. Trump. ìThe lessons in this booklet can help kids act thoughtfully and kindly,î Mrs. Trump wrote in a statement at the front of the booklet, which was labeled on the back with the Federal Trade Commissionís logo and web address. ìThe internet ó and technology in general ó are powerful forces for good.î The statement was accompanied by her official portrait.

headline: The Met Gala Comes to Jesus. Rihanna Comes as the Pope.
description: The annual benefit for the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum takes on a religious theme.
author: Jonah Engel Bromwich, Valeriya Safronova
topic_tags: , Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fashion, Anna Wintour, Rihanna
text: Each spring, a gala serves as the opening of the annual blockbuster show at the Metropolitan Museumís Costume Institute. Hundreds of celebrities arrive in a frantic seasonal migration for that party. This year, that exhibition is ìHeavenly Bodies: Fashion and the Catholic Imaginationî ó and the choice of a religious theme gave a number of gala attendees a hot chance to tee off to the line of reporters on the eventís packed red carpet on Monday night. ìIím a pagan,î said the actress Frances McDormand. ìArenít you?î ìThis is like my skin, Iím proud to be in it,î said Lena Waithe, the actress and writer, who was regally dressed in a black suit and cape that became a broad rainbow. ìIíve got the community on my back to make sure they know Iíve got them all the time.î ìThe theme to me is like be yourself,î Ms. Waithe said. ìYou were made in Godís image, right?î Not every outfit was political. ìIím the back wall of the Sistine Chapel,î said Ariana Grande, the singer, whose dress was a mass of papal conclave color. ìI feel fairly important in this outfit, I have to say.î Building a relationship with the Catholic Church took significant work by the Costume Institute curator Andrew Bolton. Eventually, the church lent more than 40 items to the exhibition, which encompasses an enormous 58,600 square feet and extends to the Cloisters. A papal tiara, with 18,000 diamonds, was flown to New York with a bodyguard. The Met Gala may be the worldís fanciest party. The ceremonial red carpet procession was to be followed by cocktails, then dinner (lobster with gold flakes was on the menu), then a dessert buffet. President Trump proposed to his wife, Melania, there in 2004. Tickets are $30,000, but you canít just buy one ó Anna Wintour, the artistic director of CondÈ Nast who is one of the chairwomen, approves attendees. And its red carpet entrance is one of the premier showcases of celebrity brands, for musicians, actors and fashion folks alike. ìThis carpet is one of the most important carpets of the year,î the model Bella Hadid said. A staff member dipped to adjust the train of the designer Ariana Rockefeller, David Rockefeller Jr.ís daughter. ìLeave her alone, sheís perfect,î a photographer shouted. ìWe based the dress on a tapestry from the Cloisters museum,î Ms. Rockefeller said. ìAnd of course my great-grandfather John D. Rockefeller Jr. founded the museum, so we really wanted to incorporate family history as well as honor the theme tonight.î Unlike in the Crusades themselves, there was very little blood shed this evening. ìThey had to sew me in on the way here,î said Olivia Munn, who was bleeding very slightly. Her dress was inspired by Crusade-era chain mail, by H&M. ìItís sewn into my head,î Ms. Hadid said of her veil. She was wearing Chrome Hearts. ìThe things we do, darling.î And, in what has become something of a tradition, one attendee used the night to seize attention. While all these celebrities flirted with the theme of Catholicism this year, none took it on as fearlessly as Rihanna, a chairwoman for the event who dressed like the female pope the Vatican has never had. Rihannaís hat was reminiscent of the papal tiaras worn by popes from the medieval era until the mid-1960s. Others were ready to take the evening less seriously. Favorite part of the night? ìEating a vegan cheeseburger right before,î said the poet Cleo Wade. Eva Chen wore an outfit inspired by Joan of Arc and said the bathroom was the place to be. ìThe secret is that is where people are partying,íí she said. ìNo, Iím joking.î Where were his kids, George Clooney was asked? ìTheyíre under the dress,î he said, waving toward the enormous train on the outfit worn by his wife, Amal, one of the eventís chairwomen. ìI forgot my ticket, do you think theyíll let me in?î asked the performer Rita Ora as she approached the entrance to the Met. They might, if they know who you are! But a feeling of religiosity did suffuse the evening. Katy Perry arrived in enormous white feathered wings. ìI feel very angelic, celestial, ethereal,î Ms. Perry said on the red carpet. ìYeah, I love God,î said the comedian Tiffany Haddish. ìGod love me ó look at my career.î The event is underwritten by Christine and Stephen A. Schwarzman, and by Versace. In addition to Rihanna, Ms. Wintour and Ms. Clooney, Donatella Versace is also a chairwoman. Ms. Wintour has led the gala since 1999. The event, said Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City, ìhas gotten better and better each year.î

headline: In Return to Cincinnati, Jay Bruce Leads Mets Out of Six-Game Slump
description: The former Red homered and Adrian Gonzalez went deep twice as the Mets‚<U+0080><U+0099> struggling offense did enough to earn a win.
author: The Associated Press
topic_tags: Baseball, Mets, Reds, Jay Bruce
text: CINCINNATI ‚<U+0080><U+0094> Jay Bruce started circling the bases and heard the roughly 15,000 fans chant his name again in that familiar way. Yes, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>BRUUUUUUCE‚<U+0080>ù was back, and so was the Mets‚<U+0080><U+0099> struggling offense. Bruce hit a two-run homer in the ballpark that‚<U+0080><U+0099>s the scene of his best moment in baseball, and Adrian Gonzalez connected twice, powering the Mets to a slump-ending 7-6 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. It was a nostalgic moment for Bruce, who was traded in 2016. He considers his top moment in sports the walk-off homer he hit at Great American Ball Park in 2010 to clinch a division title. Reds fans chanted his name in unison as he circled the bases for the 136th time there, trailing only Joey Votto (144) for the ballpark record. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Obviously every Reds fan wants the Reds to win, but we went through a lot together, ‚<U+0080>ù Bruce said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>We had a lot of time together here and a lot of experiences.‚<U+0080>ù Advertisement His third homer of the season was part of a Mets resurgence. They hit the road after getting swept during a six-game homestand that included three shutout losses and 11 runs total by their offense. Michael Conforto got it going with a leadoff homer against Homer Bailey (0-5), and Bruce had a two-run shot off his former teammate in the third for a 4-0 lead. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>We‚<U+0080><U+0099>re excited as hitters to come here, ‚<U+0080>ù said Conforto, who was in an 0-for-13 slump and had gotten the last couple days off. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>We talked about it. Here it‚<U+0080><U+0099>s a small park.‚<U+0080>ù Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. Gonzalez had a pair of solo shots as the Mets set a season high with four home runs. P.J. Conlon lasted three and two-thirds innings in his major league debut, filling in with Jacob deGrom on the disabled list because of a hyperextended elbow. Conlon also had a single off Bailey, and it wound up costing him. He hurt his thumb on the hit and it contributed to his early exit. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>I went back on the mound and I didn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t really have feeling on that thumb, ‚<U+0080>ù Conlon said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>I didn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t have a guide on any of my pitches.‚<U+0080>ù Robert Gsellman (4-0) gave up only a solo homer in two and two-thirds innings for the win. Jeurys Familia retired the side in order in the ninth with two strikeouts for his 10th save in 13 chances. Billy Hamilton, Eugenio Suarez and Scooter Gennett hit solo homers for the Reds. Cincinnati fell to 8-27, matching the worst 35-game start in franchise history along with the 1931 and 1934 teams. It‚<U+0080><U+0099>s the worst start in the majors since the Tigers had the same record in 2013. EXTRA BASES The Reds honored Mets third baseman Todd Frazier on his return to Great American Ball Park, where he won the All-Star Home Run Derby in 2015 before being traded. It was his first time back since the trade. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Me and Jay, for the last couple of months, have talked about it a lot, ‚<U+0080>ù Frazier said, referring to Jay Bruce. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>This is where we started.‚<U+0080>ù A version of this article appears in print on May 8, 2018, on Page B7 of the New York edition with the headline: Bruce, Feeling at Home in Cincinnati, Leads Mets Out of a Six-Game Slump.
