headline: How Long Would It Take Iran to Build a Nuclear Bomb? It Depends
description: It could take at least a year, maybe longer, if Iran decided to make its own fuel. But if it bought its fuel from another nuclear power, the warning time to a bomb could be about three months.
author: David E. Sanger
topic_tags: Nuclear weapon, US Foreign Policy, Nuclear energy, Hassan Rouhani, Donald Trump, Iran
text: WASHINGTON ‚<U+0080><U+0094> No sooner had President Trump declared that he was exiting the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran than Hassan Rouhani, the country‚<U+0080><U+0099>s president, reassured the world that he remained committed to making the accord work ‚<U+0080><U+0094> even if Mr. Trump did not. But he also left a vaguely worded, dangling threat: If Iran‚<U+0080><U+0099>s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, failed to keep the deal going with Europe, Russia and China, the clerical government in Tehran might conclude that America‚<U+0080><U+0099>s departure from the agreement freed it to speed up its centrifuges and begin enriching uranium at levels well above what was agreed upon in the summer of 2015. Mr. Rouhani said that he would not bend to ‚<U+0080><U+009C>psychological warfare‚<U+0080>ù from Mr. Trump and that Iran‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Atomic Energy Organization was ready to produce more nuclear fuel if necessary. All of which raised the question: If Iran tried to ramp up production, how long would it take to get enough fuel to build a bomb? Advertisement The answer is at least a year, maybe significantly longer, assuming Iran decided to make its own fuel, rather than buy it from another nuclear power. But if the nation starts down that road ‚<U+0080><U+0094> and reassembles the thousands of centrifuges that spin at supersonic speeds to enrich uranium ‚<U+0080><U+0094> the warning time to a bomb could be about three months. That is the same time frame that existed before President Barack Obama struck the nuclear deal. David Albright, the president of the Institute for Science and International Security, a private group in Washington that tracks nuclear arms, said it would currently take Iran eight to 10 months to rebuild its enrichment complex and acquire sufficient uranium fuel to make a bomb. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It‚<U+0080><U+0099>s something less than 12 months, ‚<U+0080>ù he said in an interview. That, however, is only the first step because the fuel would have to be turned into a weapon. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. Iran has studied that process for years, a point Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel made last week when he revealed a stolen trove of old Iranian documents. The documents suggest significant conceptual progress in warhead design, but it is unclear whether the Iranians know how to produce the bombs or whether its missiles have the capability to deliver them. Mr. Albright added that he expected Tehran to show restraint, at least in the near term, and keep its nuclear complex in line with the accord‚<U+0080><U+0099>s rules. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>I‚<U+0080><U+0099>m assessing they won‚<U+0080><U+0099>t do anything‚<U+0080>ù that would violate the curbs, he said. Just building up a new stockpile of uranium would take awhile. When the deal was struck in July 2015, Iran had roughly 22,000 pounds of low-enriched uranium on hand, the kind used for powering nuclear reactors. But it had to ship almost all of it out of the country. The last time inspectors issued a detailed report, they indicated that Iran had less than 250 pounds in its stockpile ‚<U+0080><U+0094> not enough to make a single nuclear weapon, even with considerable enrichment to bomb-grade levels. That is why it would probably take Iran a long while to resume production: It does not have the uranium needed to keep a larger number of centrifuges running. Building that stockpile would be difficult. And the Iranians have already made clear they have little interest in bringing back their old, inefficient centrifuges. They were working on far more powerful models before the deal was struck, but could not begin to experiment with them, under the rules of the agreement, for another seven years or so. Advertisement Now, if Tehran declares that Mr. Trump has abrogated the deal and that its restrictions are effectively lifted, it could well decide to accelerate that work. William J. Broad contributed reporting from New York.

headline: Iran, Facebook, Armenia: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s what you need to know to start your day.
author: Dan Levin
topic_tags: NA
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s the sign-up.) Good morning. President Trump pulls out of the Iran deal, Ireland tests Facebook and Armenia changes leadership. Here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s the latest: ‚<U+0080>¢ President Trump declared he was withdrawing the U.S. from the Iran nuclear accord, calling it a ‚<U+0080><U+009C>horrible one-sided deal‚<U+0080>ù that didn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t bring peace and never would. But America‚<U+0080><U+0099>s European allies have committed to staying in the deal, raising fears of a diplomatic and economic clash as the U.S. reimposes stringent sanctions on Iran. The sanctions would require European countries to reduce their oil imports from Iran, while European companies would have to close their operations there or incur penalties from the American banking system. (Here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s how the world reacted to the announcement.) Our national security correspondent sees Mr. Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s decision as a grand, highly risky bet that he can ‚<U+0080><U+009C>break the regime.‚<U+0080>ù _____ ‚<U+0080>¢ The May 25 referendum on Ireland‚<U+0080><U+0099>s abortion ban has spurred Facebook to introduce tools aimed at preventing foreign meddling in the vote, like blocking political advertising from foreign groups and letting users flag questionable ads. Advertisement The social media giant hopes to use those strategies in future elections. But the big question is whether they will work. Transparency activists have already seen a surge in online ads from questionable sources, raising concerns that foreigners are trying to influence the debate. Researchers traced ads targeting undecided voters to conservative Roman Catholic groups in the U.S. Separately, U.S. senators identified around 20 states where Russian hackers probed election systems in 2016, but found no evidence that vote tallies were changed. _____ ‚<U+0080>¢ Meet Nikol Pashinyan, a protest leader who just became Armenia‚<U+0080><U+0099>s interim prime minister. The former newspaper editor and political prisoner galvanized a civil disobedience movement that transformed the country‚<U+0080><U+0099>s political landscape in just three weeks, forcing aside the longtime president, Serzh Sargsyan. Meanwhile, Hungary‚<U+0080><U+0099>s far-right prime minister, Viktor Orban, was formally sworn in for a third term. Here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s a closer look at the ways he‚<U+0080><U+0099>s reshaped the country so far. Now Mr. Orban has the power to make constitutional changes many fear will further transform Hungary into an autocratic state. _____ ‚<U+0080>¢ Big in Europe: feathered headdress, tomahawk chops and Native American mascots. American sports teams have long faced criticism for using indigenous names and symbols in their branding. But the practice is popular among European teams and fans, who have their own ideas about what‚<U+0080><U+0099>s socially acceptable (like Buffalo Ben, above, the official team mascot for the Belgian soccer team K.A.A. Gent). Now, however, pressure to confront those stereotypes is growing, and so is their resistance to change. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>There‚<U+0080><U+0099>s a learning curve for people in Europe, but it needs to be done, ‚<U+0080>ù said a Native American woman living in England. Advertisement _____ What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. View all New York Times newsletters. ‚<U+0080>¢ Christie‚<U+0080><U+0099>s New York begins a three-day auction of a Rockefeller family art collection that could be the largest single-owner sale, and the largest charitable one, in history. Above, one of five Monets on offer. ‚<U+0080>¢ Digital currencies and artificial intelligence are turning a once-obscure computer chip into a coveted but scarce commodity. ‚<U+0080>¢ Facebook reorganized into three new divisions and shuffled the leadership of its key businesses in one of its biggest corporate shifts. ‚<U+0080>¢ The Walt Disney Company reported its strongest quarterly results in two years, but the performance was shadowed by uncertainty over its pending deal to buy most of 21st Century Fox. ‚<U+0080>¢ Here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s a snapshot of global markets. ‚<U+0080>¢ A shell company that President Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s lawyer Michael Cohen, above, used to pay hush money to a pornographic film actress received payments from a firm linked to a Russian oligarch. [The New York Times] ‚<U+0080>¢ In Germany, three baby girls have been found abandoned, a year apart, in and around Berlin. DNA tests show all three had the same parents. [The New York Times] ‚<U+0080>¢ Britain‚<U+0080><U+0099>s upper house of Parliament voted in favor of staying in the E.U.‚<U+0080><U+0099>s single market after Brexit, challenging the government of Prime Minister Theresa May. [BBC] ‚<U+0080>¢ Italy‚<U+0080><U+0099>s deal with Libya to stop migrants reaching Europe is facing a legal challenge over allegations that it subjects migrants to grave human rights violations, including torture and slavery. [The Guardian] Advertisement ‚<U+0080>¢ A former C.I.A. officer suspected of helping China dismantle the agency‚<U+0080><U+0099>s spy network in that country was charged with conspiring to commit espionage. [The New York Times] Tips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life. ‚<U+0080>¢ Recipe of the day: Broccoli comes to life with orange and sesame. ‚<U+0080>¢ Organize your home to create a more relaxed and efficient life. ‚<U+0080>¢ You need a good, 10-foot charging cable for your phone. ‚<U+0080>¢ The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra‚<U+0080><U+0099>s after-school music program has become a refuge for children, above, in a city plagued by poverty and gun violence. Some students have gone on to play with famous musicians, including the cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis. ‚<U+0080>¢ In memoriam: Ermanno Olmi, 86, an Italian film director who chronicled his country‚<U+0080><U+0099>s 20th-century evolution from a backward agrarian economy into an industrial giant. ‚<U+0080>¢ And in one of our most-read stories today, our Op-Ed columnist Bari Weiss looks at the Intellectual Dark Web, an alliance of iconoclastic thinkers, academic renegades and media personalities that is making an end run around the mainstream conversation, and drawing attention around the world. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>People are starved for controversial opinions, ‚<U+0080>ù one member said. Peter Pan helps sick children. Not fictionally, financially. The author J.M. Barrie, above, who was born on this day in 1860, donated the rights to his most famous creation to the Great Ormond Street children‚<U+0080><U+0099>s hospital in London in 1929. In a front-page report at the time, The New York Times estimated their worth at ‚<U+0080><U+009C>roughly $10,000 a year, ‚<U+0080>ù which it said was equivalent to a sixth of the hospital‚<U+0080><U+0099>s income. It would have been clear that the gift was of lasting value: The boy who never grows up was introduced in 1902, becoming the subject of a hit play two years later, and then a novel. He had already inspired a statue in a London park, and even begun his long career in movies. Advertisement But few would have guessed quite how long Peter Pan would pay. The copyright first expired in Britain at the end of 1987, 50 years after Barrie‚<U+0080><U+0099>s death. Within months, however, Parliament passed a measure granting Great Ormond Street a permanent right to royalties from the stage play and adaptations of it. Peter Pan‚<U+0080><U+0099>s adventures in America are also still helping the hospital; according to its website, the U.S. copyright does not expire until 2023. Peter Robins wrote today‚<U+0080><U+0099>s Back Story. _____ Your Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. Check out this page to find a Morning Briefing for your region. (In addition to our European edition, we have Australian, Asian and U.S. editions.) Sign up here to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights, and here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s our full range of free newsletters. What would you like to see here? Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com. Follow Dan Levin on Twitter: @globaldan.

headline: Iran, Schneiderman, Met Gala: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s what you need to know at the end of the day.
author: Karen Zraick, David Scull
topic_tags: NA
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s the sign-up.) Good evening. Here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s the latest. 1. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It didn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t bring calm, it didn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t bring peace, and it never will.‚<U+0080>ù President Trump announced his decision to withdraw the U.S. from the ‚<U+0080><U+009C>horrible one-sided‚<U+0080>ù Iran nuclear deal. The move fulfilled a campaign vow, isolated the U.S. from many allies, and raised further fears for the Iranian economy, which is already in free fall. Our national security correspondent sees Mr. Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s decision as a grand, highly risky bet that he can ‚<U+0080><U+009C>break the regime.‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Trump also announced that Secretary of State Mike Pompeo was headed to North Korea, raising hopes that several Americans might be released. Advertisement ____ 2. Who will succeed Eric Schneiderman? Will he face criminal prosecution? And what will happen to his legal challenges to President Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s policies? Many questions are swirling after the resignation of the New York attorney general, who had positioned himself as a foe of Mr. Trump and a defender of women‚<U+0080><U+0099>s rights. He resigned on Monday night after four women accused him of abuse in an article published in The New Yorker. The accusations included alcohol-fueled rages, racist remarks, prescription drug abuse and threats ‚<U+0080><U+0094> including to kill the women or use his power as the state‚<U+0080><U+0099>s top law enforcement officer against them if they defied him. ____ 3. Five more top executives left Nike amid a sweeping investigation into allegations of harassment and discrimination against female employees. That brings the number of senior executives who have left to 11. They had run some of the highest-profile departments at the world‚<U+0080><U+0099>s largest sports footwear and apparel company, and a big question is whether their successors can hit the ground running. Nike shares fell 1.27 percent, to $68.46. Above, the company‚<U+0080><U+0099>s headquarters in Beaverton, Ore. ____ 4. Voters in Indiana, Ohio and West Virginia went to the polls in important Republican Senate primaries. The winners will all face vulnerable Democratic incumbents in November, in races that could determine the balance of the Senate. Here‚<U+0080><U+0099>s a closer look at what‚<U+0080><U+0099>s at stake in each race. We‚<U+0080><U+0099>ll be tallying the results as they come in. ____ 5. Gina Haspel, President Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s nominee to run the C.I.A., faces a much-anticipated confirmation hearing on Wednesday before the Senate Intelligence Committee. Advertisement Mr. Trump chose Ms. Haspel because she is a seasoned veteran of the agency. But that has become her greatest weakness, as critics pick apart her role in some of the agency‚<U+0080><U+0099>s darkest chapters, involving torture and secret prisons. We discussed Ms. Haspel‚<U+0080><U+0099>s controversial past on our podcast ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The Daily.‚<U+0080>ù And on the eve of the hearing, there was a new twist: The principal architect of the Sept. 11 attacks, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, asked a judge at Guant√°namo for permission to share unspecified information about Ms. Haspel with the committee. ____ 6. Meet Nikol Pashinyan, a protest leader who just became Armenia‚<U+0080><U+0099>s interim prime minister. The former newspaper editor and political prisoner galvanized a civil disobedience movement that transformed the country‚<U+0080><U+0099>s political landscape in just three weeks, forcing aside the longtime president, Serzh Sargsyan. The question now is whether Mr. Pashinyan can fulfill his promise to jump-start the country‚<U+0080><U+0099>s moribund economy. ____ 7. Heroin is scourging rural parts of Northern California. We went to Humboldt County, a coastal area long celebrated as a gateway to the scenic Redwood Empire. The opioid death rate there is five times higher than the state average, rivaling the widely reported tolls in states like Maine and Vermont. Residents complain of syringe litter and people shooting up in public. The problem is worsened by a sizable and still growing homeless population, an extreme lack of affordable housing and a weak local economy. Some users take meth to keep moving at night, when they‚<U+0080><U+0099>re most vulnerable to the police, and then turn to heroin during the day to feed their cravings. ____ 8. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>There were cardinals! There were priests! There were Madonnas (and Madonna, who seemed to have gone from like a virgin to like a Sicilian widow in black Jean Paul Gaultier)! There were angels, and crusaders and icons-dressed-as-icons. There was impossible-to-resist word play.‚<U+0080>ù Advertisement That was our fashion critic‚<U+0080><U+0099>s review of the red carpet at the Met Gala. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The dress code was ‚<U+0080><U+0098>Sunday Best, ‚<U+0080><U+0099> and never, even in the annals of Met Galas past, have boldfaced names raced so wholeheartedly toward a theme, ‚<U+0080>ù she added. See the wild looks for yourself in our slideshow. ____ 9. Christie‚<U+0080><U+0099>s New York begins a three-day auction of a Rockefeller family art collection that could be the largest single-owner sale, and the largest charitable one, in history. The house will offer masterpieces by Matisse and Picasso, as well as truckloads of valuable porcelain. Highlights from the collection have been touring the globe to increase anticipation. Above, one of five Monets on offer. ____ 10. Finally, the late-night hosts had a wealth of material after President Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s newest lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, did another batch of TV interviews over the weekend. The key takeaway, according to Seth Meyers: ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Trump‚<U+0080><U+0099>s going to be the first client who pleads insanity on behalf of his lawyer.‚<U+0080>ù Have a great night. ____ Get a nightly rundown of the day‚<U+0080><U+0099>s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday. headline: James Paxton Couldnít Be Hit. Dylan Bundy Couldnít Get an Out
description: Paxton, the Seattle Mariners starter, threw the seasonís third no-hitter on Tuesday in Toronto, while Bundy had a historically bad outing for the Baltimore Orioles.
author: Benjamin Hoffman
topic_tags: Baseball, Orioles, Mariners,,
text: One pitched nine innings and did not allow a hit. The other faced seven batters and did not record an out. It is hard to imagine two starts in one night being more different than the ones recorded by James Paxton of the Seattle Mariners and Dylan Bundy of the Baltimore Orioles on Tuesday. Paxton, a 29-year-old from Ladner, British Columbia, became the first Canadian to throw a no-hitter in Canada when he blanked the Toronto Blue Jays, striking out seven and allowing three walks for a 5-0 victory and the third no-hitter of the season. Bundy, a 25-year-old right-hander, took the hill against the Kansas City Royals and threw 28 pitches to seven batters. By the time Baltimore Manager Buck Showalter came out to pull him for a reliever, he had allowed five hits (four of which were home runs) and two walks, and all seven batters had scored. By the statistic Game Score, which was developed by Bill James to evaluate the overall performance of a pitcher, and then adjusted some in recent years by the statistician Tom Tango, the disparity between the efforts of the two starters was rather extreme. Paxton recorded a 95 under the Tango method, and Bundy recorded a minus-19. It was nearly as extreme under the James method, with Paxton edging Bundy 91 to 10, which according to Baseball Reference ties Paxton for the seasonís fifth-best start and tied Bundy for the 12th-worst. In truth, it is hard to imagine there being 11 starts worse than Bundyís, but Baseball Reference credits Matt Moore of the Texas Rangers with the worst start of the year. Just last week, Moore threw four innings, giving up 11 hits and 10 runs (all earned) while striking out one and walking two. That generated a Game Score of minus-1 under the James method. (Tangoís method actually has Bundyís start as the worst of the season, with that formula generating a score of minus-9 for Moore). It is all splitting hairs, of course, as Bundy, who actually tied for the highest Game Score in the majors last season with a 95, was mercifully saved by his manager in a start where he had no answers. Paxton, on the other hand, needed just 99 pitches to steamroll the Blue Jays in the first complete game of his career. All three of his walks came in the first four innings, and he got some help from his defense, with spectacular plays by Kyle Seager, Dee Gordon and Ben Gamel all helping contribute to the 299th official no-hitter in M.L.B. history.

headline: Jay-Z Is Ordered to Testify in Case Involving His Former Fashion Brand
description: A federal judge is requiring him to testify as part of an investigation into a company that paid more than $200 million for assets related to Rocawear.
author: Colin Moynihan
topic_tags: Securities fraud, Decisions and Verdicts, Jay Z, Rocawear, Paul G Gardephe, Music, Fashion
text: A federal judge on Tuesday ordered the rapper and entrepreneur Jay-Z to testify as part of a securities investigation into a company that paid him more than $200 million in 2007 for assets including some related to the Rocawear brand. During months of back and forth in response to subpoenas, lawyers for Jay-Z sought to limit his testimony in the case. They said that he had been on tour when his testimony was first requested and that he was now preparing for another. Last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission filed court papers asking that a judge order Jay-Z, whose actual name is Shawn Carter, to comply with a subpoena to testify. In their most recent response, the lawyers sought to limit any testimony to a single day. But the S.E.C. resisted limits, and the judge sided with its lawyers. ìIím granting the S.E.C.ís application to enforce the subpoena,î Judge Paul G. Gardephe of Federal District Court in Manhattan, said in court Tuesday. ìThe testimony has been delayed for five months, and I do not intend to tolerate any further delay.î The S.E.C. is investigating whether federal securities laws were violated in connection with Iconix Brand Group Inc.ís ìreporting of intangible assets, including the Rocawear assets.î Iconix wrote down the Rocawear brand by about $169 million for the year ending 2015 and by about $34 million for the year ending in 2017. The government wrote that after the sale, Iconix reported that Mr. Carter remained involved with the Rocawear brand and that he and Iconix maintained certain business partnerships. The S.E.C. said that it wanted to question him about, among other things, the value of the Rocawear trademark; his involvement with the brand after the sale; and ìmultiple emails, meetings and phone calls related to Iconix.î After briefly conferring on Tuesday, lawyers told Judge Gardephe that Mr. Carter would testify on May 15, an agreement that would appear to resolve a standoff over the scope of the subpoena and how much time Mr. Carter should make available. In court papers, the S.E.C. had said that an examination of Mr. Carter would ìtake at least a full day of testimony.î The S.E.C. said that it sent subpoenas to Mr. Carter in November and February but that in emails and phone calls his lawyers said he would not comply unless the testimony was limited to four hours. Mr. Carter eventually agreed to a full day, and his lawyers wrote that the S.E.C. had ìno legal warrant to insist upon more.î In court papers, Mr. Carters lawyers said the S.E.C.ís request should be denied because the government had not shown that his testimony was relevant and because compliance would impose an unreasonable hardship. The S.E.C., they added, had rejected their offers to provide information through a lawyer or telephone interview. They called the S.E.C. request ìunreasonably and unnecessarily burdensomeî and said it was ìdriven more by governmental fascination with celebrity and headlines than by any proper investigative purpose.î Judge Gardephe suggested that it was not up to Mr. Carterís lawyers to determine what information the S.E.C. should pursue, and he declined to institute time restrictions for his testimony. ìLimits sometimes incentivize respondents to waste time,î he said, adding that they might then want to ìin effect, run out the clock.î

headline: John Mulaney Thinks Comics Should Take the Gloves Off
description: The comedian on the challenges ó or not ó of joke-writing in our current political climate.
author: Molly Lambert
topic_tags: Comedy, US Politics, Netflix, John Mulaney, Donald Trump
text: Your new stand-up special is out on Netflix now, which you performed in a lot of big, beautiful theaters, including Radio City Music Hall. Are there any big venues you still dream about playing? I want to do ìOh, Helloî live at the Acropolis. Just because only Yanni has done that so far. You have a habit of checking out local historic sites when youíre on tour. Is there any one in particular that you love? Have you ever been to the Teddy Roosevelt townhouse? He grew up in a townhouse in Chelsea thatís pretty well preserved, and this one woman is ecstatic if you want to take a tour. Does it have a lot of hunting trophies? Yes, it had a lot of birds that he taxidermied. And I remember her saying that he often had trouble on dates because he always smelled like formaldehyde. Theyíd be like, ìYou smell like formaldehyde,î and heíd be like: ìAh, bully bully! I killed a bird and stuffed it.î Do you consider yourself a presidential-history buff? I used to be a total Lisa Simpson about it; I used to be able to recite all the presidents, start to finish. I canít do that anymore. Now I have all the dead spots other people have. You know, John Tyler, I couldnít tell you much about him. If you were going to play a president, whom would you want to play, and why? William Henry Harrison. He was very funny because he was president for one month. He gave way too long of an inaugural address, where he caught pneumonia, and he died a month later. That would be great: A president planning his whole presidency and doesnít know heís going to die in a month. ìAll right, letís focus on the first 100 days. Hand me that pen as I cough for 10 minutes. O.K., anyway. Letís talk about roads.î How are you feeling about the current moment in politics? Iíve got to say, there are times I wish the election had gone the other way. Where do you feel comedy fits in? Do you feel as if itís an escape from reality, or do you feel responsibility to talk about things that are happening? I feel a responsibility to try to be as funny as possible. Weíre talking about an hour of their night thatís a release ó not pretending things arenít happening. I love comedians that dive into politics. I personally donít feel comfortable, with my background, weighing in unless I have a take that I think is funny enough that I would put it in front of an audience. Do you feel that itís a weird environment for satire? No. I donít mean to be glib, but I donít think itís a hard time for comics. Patton Oswalt has a bit about this that I will poorly paraphrase: Thereís so much stuff that you canít even make fun of the most current thing. Like, you write a joke about one thing Trumpís done and then 20 seconds later, heís done something even worse. I donít think itís hard to make fun of the biggest laughingstocks in the world who are in the news all day long. I do think itís hard to be original about it. You used to write for ìSaturday Night Live,î which the president sometimes seems to watch. Would it be tempting if you were still there to intentionally anger him? I mean, the standards have changed because he changed the standards of acceptability. Around 2012, when I was still there, we had a sketch with a sort of light, not too mean, cutaway to all of Mitt Romneyís sons ó it was a B-minus joke. It was just, like, ìOh, theyíre robotic, and theyíre all named Tad or whatever.î And we really debated it because, well, what have these children of his done? Whatís the point of making fun of them? And there was a general standard of not doing that. But now ìS.N.L.î regularly mocks Eric and Donald Jr., as they should. You bring your stupid kids on TV and force them into your White House, then those particular kids are fair game.

headline: Like a Tattoo, This Wedding Favor Is Forever
description: ìThere were some people who were too drunk to get tattoos,î said one bride. So, a groomsman became an informal ink bouncer. Others have been ìjust drunk enough to concede.î
author: Alicia Kennedy
topic_tags: Weddings and Engagements, Tattoo
text: Lindsay Morris and Stephen Munshin didnít have to step inside a tattoo parlor to get their first tattoos. All they had to do was attend the wedding of their niece Leslie Merinoff to Brian Kwasienski last October in Bushwick, Brooklyn. Ms. Morris and Mr. Munshin were aware there would be tattoos available during the reception. ìAnd we were not planning on getting one,î said Ms. Morris, a photographer. But by the end of the night, the Sag Harbor, N.Y., couple, who managed to stay ink-free into their early 50s, were using up a tattoo artistís last needles to have the number ì11î put on their wrists. Both were born on that day of the month. ìI guess the idea of it being small and quick made it more inviting,î said Mr. Munshin, the publisher of Edible magazines in the New York area. ìIt didnít seem as much of a challenge or investment. It was Lindsayís encouragement. I was just drunk enough to concede.î The occasion of a beloved nieceís wedding imbues the tattoos with more meaning, and it was, Mr. Munshin noted, ìa cool party.î Not surprisingly, both bride and groom sported tattoos. Ms. Merinoffís designs make up what she calls a ìroad map of her lifeî that signify special moments. When she pulls up the sleeves of her sweater in an attempt to get a count, she gives up almost immediately. While planning her wedding, she said she thought, ìWhat better moment to really keep forever?î Ms. Merinoff and Mr. Kwasienski, who are opening a boutique distillation company in Greenport, N.Y., chose the tattoo artist Bryce Oprandi of the Los Angeles area to work at their wedding. Ms. Merinoff had become a big fan of his work after following him on Instagram. When they met for drinks in New York, she said, she immediately asked him to be at the wedding simply for his laid-back energy. ìI thought to myself, ëI want this guy around,íî she said. The couple covered his travel and accommodations, as well as a flat rate for his time. They had planned for only a few of the 400-plus guests to get small tattoos from a limited selection featuring a coupe glass, the wedding date and others. But Mr. Oprandi ended up working on a couple dozen guests up until the end of the night. Tattoo artists are one way to subvert and personalize longstanding traditions, much like having mixed gender bridesmaids and groomsmen. ìSocial media has created a world where individuality is celebrated and personal brands are curated, so we find that same notion being implemented into weddings,î said Kristen Maxwell Cooper, the editor in chief of the Knot, a wedding website. ìCouples no longer want something cookie cutter. They want to throw an amazing party that truly feels like who they are as a couple.î Robert Fiore, an artist from Lansdale, Pa., who has been tattooing for 22 years, recently made weddings his whole business. He started the Wedding Tattooer last June, and since then, has gotten more than 2,000 inquiries for his services. For these events, Mr. Fiore creates a set of four to six small designs, each about the size of a golf ball, from which guests can choose. Heíll tattoo on legs, arms or shoulders. Chests and other more risquÈ body parts, he says, are generally off-limits. Mr. Fiore started this business almost by accident. ìIn November of 2016, my cousin was getting married, and a few months prior, he called me to say he wanted to have something ëawesomeí at the reception,î Mr. Fiore said. ìWe were going over ideas and I said, ëWhat if I just came down there and tattooed?íî His most extensive package costs $1,250, which covers as many guests as he can tattoo over four hours. Each design takes about 10 to 15 minutes to complete, and he brings an assistant who places the stencil on each client and bandages the tattoos after theyíre complete. Mr. Fiore is not just called upon by the heavily tattooed. ìCouples and guests who wouldnít generally seek out a tattoo, when theyíre amongst their family and friends, theyíre feeling the moment,î he said. ìThat would be the one time that someone who has no interest in getting tattooed would.î What makes the wedding circuit so exciting, he said, is ìthe crossover.î Karen Glass, a Brooklyn artist, tattooed at one wedding more than three years ago and found it to be a transformative experience for the attendees. ìWe were busy the whole night ó a lot of people got tattooed,î she said. ìWe did a few peopleís first tattoos, including the mother of the groom. The guests were cheering and taking so many photos. It seemed to be an amazing experience for everyone.î Even those who didnít get inked were entertained. ìMost people love watching it happen,î Ms. Glass said. ìItís a great crowd-pleaser.î At Ms. Merinoffís wedding, not just aunts and uncles got their first tattoos, but friends as well. ìEveryone was so happy,î she said. ìThe space was so beautiful. Thereís a feeling that you donít want it to end, so you take a little bit of that energy and keep it forever.î Some guests, though, were not quite up to taking home such a permanent wedding favor. ìThere were some people who were too drunk to get tattoos,î Ms. Merinoff said. In those cases, a groomsman ìran interferenceî as an ink bouncer. Mr. Munshin and Ms. Morris look back fondly on their decision to get tattoos. ìIt was a little bit romantic,î Mr. Munshin said, ìand a little bit for amusement.î ìI like the way they peek out from whatever shirt Iím wearing,î Ms. Morris added. ìIt makes me happy.î

headline: How a Low-Carb Diet Might Aid People With Type 1 Diabetes
description: Children and adults with Type 1 diabetes who followed a low-carb, high-protein diet had ìexceptionalî blood sugar control and low rates of complications.
author: Anahad Oíconnor
topic_tags: Diabetes, Nutrition, Carbohydrates, Children, Insulin
text: Like many children, Andrew Hightower, 13, likes pizza, sandwiches and dessert. But Andrew has Type 1 diabetes, and six years ago, in order to control his blood sugar levels, his parents put him on a low-carbohydrate, high-protein diet. His mother makes him recipes with diabetic-friendly ingredients that wonít spike his blood sugar, like pizza with a low-carb, almond-flour crust; homemade bread with walnut flour instead of white flour; and yogurt topped with blueberries, raspberries and nuts. Andrewís diet requires careful planning ó he often takes his own meals with him to school. But he and his parents say it makes it easier to manage his condition and, since starting the diet, his blood sugar control has markedly improved and he has not had any diabetes complications requiring trips to the hospital. ìI do this so that I can be healthy,î Andrew, who lives with his parents in Jacksonville, Fla., said of his diet. ìWhen I eventually move out and go to college, Iím going to keep up what Iím doing because Iím on the right path.î Most diabetes experts do not recommend low-carb diets for people with Type 1 diabetes, especially children. Some worry that restricting carbs can lead to dangerously low blood sugar levels, a condition known as hypoglycemia, and potentially stunt a childís growth. But a new study published in the journal Pediatrics on Monday suggests otherwise. It found that children and adults with Type 1 diabetes who followed a very low-carb, high-protein diet for an average of just over two years ó combined with the diabetes drug insulin at smaller doses than typically required on a normal diet ó had ìexceptionalî blood sugar control. They had low rates of major complications, and children who followed it for years did not show any signs of impaired growth. The study found that the participantsí average hemoglobin A1C a long-term barometer of blood sugar levels, fell to just 5.67 percent. An A1C under 5.7 is considered normal, and it is well below the threshold for diabetes, which is 6.5 percent. ìTheir blood sugar control seemed almost too good to be true,î said Belinda Lennerz, the lead author of the study and an instructor in the division of pediatric endocrinology at Boston Childrenís Hospital and Harvard Medical School. ìItís nothing we typically see in the clinic for Type 1 diabetes.î The new study comes with an important caveat. It was an observational study, not a randomized trial with a control group. The researchers recruited 316 people, 130 of them children whose parents gave consent, from a Facebook group dedicated to low-carb diets for diabetes, called TypeOneGrit, then reviewed their medical records and contacted their medical providers. While it was not a clinical trial, the study is striking because it highlights a community of patients who have been ìextraordinarily successfulî at controlling their diabetes with a very low-carb diet, said Dr. David M. Harlan, the co-director of the Diabetes Center of Excellence at the UMass Memorial Medical Center, who was not involved in the study. ìPerhaps the surprise is that for this large number of patients it is much safer than many experts would have suggested.î ìIím excited to see this paper,î Dr. Harlan added. . ìIt should reopen the discussion about whether this is something we should be offering our patients as a therapeutic approach.î The authors of the paper cautioned that the findings should not lead patients to alter their diabetes management without consulting their doctors, and that large clinical trials will be necessary to determine whether this approach should be used more widely. ìWe think the findings point the way to a potentially exciting new treatment option,î said Dr. David Ludwig, a co-author of the study and a pediatric endocrinologist at Boston Childrenís Hospital who has written popular books about low-carb diets. ìHowever, because our study was observational, the results should not, by themselves, justify a change in diabetes management.î About 1.25 million Americans have Type 1 diabetes, which occurs when the pancreas does not produce enough insulin to regulate blood sugar levels. Managing the condition requires administering insulin throughout the day, especially when consuming meals high in carbs, which raise blood sugar more than other nutrients. Over time, chronically elevated blood sugar can lead to nerve and kidney damage and cardiovascular disease. The standard approach for people with Type 1 diabetes is to match carb intake with insulin. But the argument for restricting carbs is that it keeps blood sugar more stable and requires less insulin, resulting in fewer highs and lows. The approach has not been widely studied or embraced for Type 1 diabetes, but some patients swear by it. TypeOneGrit has about 3,000 members on Facebook who ascribe to a program devised by Dr. Richard Bernstein, an 84-year-old physician with Type 1 diabetes. His book, ìDr. Bernsteinís Diabetes Solution,î recommends limiting daily carb intake to about 30 grams, the amount in a sweet potato or about four or five cups of cooked broccoli. Dr. Bernstein argues that the fewer carbs consumed, the easier it is to stabilize blood sugar with insulin. He recommends foods like nonstarchy vegetables, seafood, nuts, meat, yogurt, tofu and recipes made with almond flour, sugar substitutes and other low-glycemic ingredients. His plan emphasizes protein intake, which he says is especially important for growing children. Dr. Carrie Diulus, an orthopedic surgeon with Type 1 diabetes who follows a low-carb vegan diet, credits the Bernstein approach with helping her keep her blood sugar under control. ìIt allows me to perform complex spine surgeries without worrying about my diabetes because my blood sugar stays relatively stable,î said Dr. Diulus, who helped inspire the new study when researchers learned about her participation in the TypeOneGrit community. The most striking finding of the new report was that A1C levels, on average, fell from 7.15 percent, in the diabetic range, to 5.67 percent, which is normal. The rate of diabetes-related hospitalizations also fell, from 8 percent before the diet to 2 percent after, including fewer hospitalizations for hypoglycemic seizures. Those following the diet had increased LDL cholesterol, likely from consuming more saturated fat, which some experts said was potentially concerning and deserved further study. But other heart disease risk factors appeared favorable: They had high HDL cholesterol, the protective kind, and low triglycerides, a type of fat in the blood linked to heart disease. Dr. Joyce Lee, a diabetes expert at the University of Michigan who was not involved in the study, said the findings were impressive and merited further follow-up, and that patients who wanted to explore a low-carb approach might do so while being monitored by their health care team. But she also noted that the patients in the new study were a ìhighly motivatedî group, and that it would be difficult for many people to adopt the restrictive regimen they followed. ìThe reality is that itís really hard to do low-carb, given our cultural norms,î said Dr. Lee, a professor of pediatrics at the University of Michigan. In an interview, Dr. Bernstein, a co-author on the paper, said it demonstrates what he sees in his practice: That there are diabetics on his regimen ìwho are walking around with normal blood sugars and they are happy about it, healthy, and growing if they are kids.î Derek Raulerson, 46, a human resources manager in Alabama, agrees. Both he and his son, Connor, 13, have Type 1 diabetes. Mr. Raulerson said he struggled for years to control his blood sugar. But six years ago, he gave up juice, bread, potatoes and other simple carbs, and made protein and nonstarchy vegetables the focus of his meals. Since going low-carb, he said, he has lost weight, cut in half the amount of insulin he uses daily, and watched his A1C fall from the diabetic range to normal levels. ìI have normalized, steady blood sugars now,î he said. ìI am no longer on the roller coaster.î

headline: In Lullabies, a Chance for Parent and Child to Bond
description: Singing can help soothe a baby to sleep, but it has benefits for the parent as well.
author: Perri Klass, M.d.
topic_tags: Music, Babies, Parenting, Sleep, Carnegie Hall
text: When you sing a lullaby to your baby, you convey love and language and dreams of the future ó and also, of course, you are trying to help your baby to a more immediate future of being asleep. Singing helps calm both the baby and the parent, experts say, and creates a bedtime ritual to signal a transition from the dayís activities. Carnegie Hallís Weill Music Institute created a lullaby project to help mothers bond with their babies. Tiffany Ortiz, the manager of the project, said it started in 2011 with a pilot at Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx, where staff members noticed that some teenage parents were having trouble attaching to their children. It has expanded across New York City, with artists working with parents at different sites, including high schools, hospitals, clinics, shelters and the Rikers Island jail, and is now being replicated nationally and internationally. Teaching artists work with parents, who draft a letter which speaks to their hopes and dreams for the child, Ms. Ortiz said, and the lyrics emerge from those messages. ìThen thereís a discussion about the musical side of it, how they want it to sound,î she said. ìUsually, parents will start to hum.î After the lullaby is created, it is recorded for the parent to keep, to refer to, to sing again and again. ìI am surprised by how rich and complicated parenting is, and how much music making in parenting is that way too,î said Emily Eagen, a musician and songwriter who has been a teaching artist in the program since 2011. When the project started, Ms. Eagen was pregnant. She is now getting her doctorate, and does research on lullabies from around the world, noting that lullabies can reflect many of the complexities of taking care of children, ìhow hard it is to exercise a certain amount of structure, how painful it is that they have to go through something hard,î like the separation and solitude associated with going to sleep. Anita Collins, a music educator who researches brain development and music, said that babies are born with relatively undeveloped sight but, under most circumstances, with perfect hearing. ìBabiesí auditory processing or hearing sense is actually the most important sense they have for the first two years of their lives, the sense that gathers the most information about their world,î said Dr. Collins, an associate fellow in music, mind and well-being at the University of Melbourne, Australia, and the author of the forthcoming book ìThe Lullaby Effect.î On April 20, the Carnegie Hall project released ìHopes and Dreams,î a recording of 15 original lullabies written by parents in New York from 2011 to 2015, performed by a range of artists, including Joyce DiDonato, Fiona Apple, Lawrence Brownlee and Patti LuPone. The goal of the project, though, is for parents to sing themselves, Ms. Ortiz said, to ìembed more singing into daily practice and into parentsí lives, shatter that notion they might not be able to sing or theyíre out of tune ó for a child, their voice is going to mean the most.î ìLullabies are very natural, but thereís not the perfect list of lullabies,î Dr. Collins said. ìItís about holding that child, looking them in the face, rocking them so they get the sense of the rhythm and the movement.î Researchers have looked at the ways that infants respond to maternal singing. But in research studies comparing babies who were held and talked to or left in their cribs and sung to, she said, the babies went to sleep more quickly if they were sung to. ìItís about having that connection they feel when someone sings to them.î Ms. Eagen recalled working with a mother who talked about the connection she felt to her baby when she saw the heart beating on the sonogram. ìThe doctor said, youíre the only one who will have this babyís heart beat inside you, youíll know each otherís heartbeat,î and that became the lullaby: Iím the only one who knows your heartbeat, and youíre the only one who knows my heartbeat. For a family with a baby in the neonatal intensive care unit, ìwe wrote a song: ëWeíre waiting for you to come home, and weíll celebrate with all the balloons in the worldí ó we were all in tears,î she said. ìItís very transformative. You donít know how much singing and writing a song is going to feel like you have agency ó it really does make a difference to do this.î Lullabies are important for the babies who hear them, but also for the parents who sing them, said Dr. Dennie Palmer Wolf, the principal researcher on the project, who put together research summaries on the importance of making music and on lullabies and wellness. ìMost of the mothers we worked with in New York live under very stressful conditions,î such as having a sick baby in the NICU or being homeless. ìRestoring a sense of positive well-being is extremely important; unless parents have that to draw on, itís hard to be consistent and emotionally available for their children.î ìFor a lot of women itís the first time theyíve written a song or even written poetry,î said Ms. Eagen. ìTheyíre love songs and theyíre work songs. Thereís a lot in lullabies about letting yourself do the work of parenting, calming yourself down,î she said. ìThe mothers get a lot out of being able to sing the song to themselves as well as to the child.î And, of course, lullabies are also about helping babies say good night. In a new show on the site Scary Mommy called ìLullaby League,î shot in New York homes, a cappella groups compete to sing babies to sleep. Micaela Birmingham, the siteís head of video and creator of the show, said the idea came out of watching friends who were desperate for a good nightís sleep, and putting that together with a fondness for a cappella music. They put out a casting call for a cappella singers and went into the houses of babies from 2 to 14 months, choosing families who were struggling with bedtime. When they made the pilot, with the group singing outside the babyís door, Ms. Birmingham said, they wondered whether it would have any effect. ìIt worked,î she said. ìThere was something mesmerizing about the singing, even with a bunch of strangers and cameras, and these were babies who were notoriously hard to get to sleep,î she said. The show is structured as a contest in which the singing groups are racing the clock to see who can put the baby to sleep fastest; the final championship round involves soothing a pair of twins. Jim OíHeir, the host, likes a cappella singing ó ìit just soothes my soulî ó but he didnít expect it to be particularly effective with babies. ìI was kind of blown away by it,î he said. ìThere were some babies wailing, really going at it. They hear this music, they look around: ëWhat is this?í Next thing you know, theyíre sitting down, theyíre laying down. Mom goes, ëThis babyís asleep.íî And this is the age when brains are connecting. ìLullabies allow infants to create neural pathways for calming down, soothing, falling asleep,î especially important in the early months of life when brain pathways are being created, Dr. Palmer Wolf said. ìA lullaby is an external routine that becomes an internal pathway for calming down.î

headline: A Radical Artist Takes a Startling Turn Toward Love
description: Known for politically charged social art, Marlene Dumas tries a new direction ‚<U+0080><U+0094> Eros ‚<U+0080><U+0094> inspired by Shakespeare.
author: Nina Siegal
topic_tags: Art, Books, David Zwirner, Amsterdam, Poetry
text: AMSTERDAM ‚<U+0080><U+0094> A painting by Marlene Dumas of her pregnant daughter Helena ‚<U+0080><U+0094> her belly wide and full, her hands raised at the elbow, her feet splayed ‚<U+0080><U+0094> stood nearly 10 feet tall in the South African artist‚<U+0080><U+0099>s studio here two weeks ago. It was the night before a few dozen of Ms. Dumas‚<U+0080><U+0099>s new paintings would be shipped to New York for her first solo exhibition there in eight years, and the artist was drinking white wine and still contemplating which works would ultimately end up in the show. Several other monumental nudes, both male and female, were propped against the walls in two light-filled studio spaces, representing what she calls ‚<U+0080><U+009C>strange, mixed-up figures, not quite human.‚<U+0080>ù Interspersed among them were smaller oil paintings of bodily fragments: a lipstick-smeared mouth, a single breast and several renditions of two faces entwined in a kiss. Ms. Dumas, 64, walked through the space, its floor littered with half-squeezed paint tubes and its tables topped with art history books, museum postcards and photocopied images. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>They are, in a sense, individual works, ‚<U+0080>ù she said of the paintings, but they all have something to do with ‚<U+0080><U+009C>attraction, sensuality and desires.‚<U+0080>ù Advertisement This is Ms. Dumas‚<U+0080><U+0099>s newest body of work, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Myths & Mortals, ‚<U+0080>ù which just opened at David Zwirner‚<U+0080><U+0099>s West 20th Street gallery in Manhattan and is on view through June 30. Half of the 61 works were painted in the last three months, she said, while others were from 2016 and 2017. They start with a series of ink wash illustrations Ms. Dumas made to accompany a narrative Shakespeare poem, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Venus and Adonis, ‚<U+0080>ù which inspired her to explore issues of eroticism, but also power and violence. They led her to examine similar themes in a series of paintings. Ms. Dumas is known for politically charged social art, often based on Polaroid snapshots, disturbing images clipped out of newspapers, or film stills appropriated from pornography. She has taken a radically new direction in this body of work: painting on significantly larger canvasses; using a more vibrant, chromatic palette; and stepping into mythological terrain. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>These works are really about the human condition, about people in their most basic state: They‚<U+0080><U+0099>re naked, they‚<U+0080><U+0099>re pregnant, they‚<U+0080><U+0099>re getting married, they‚<U+0080><U+0099>re kissing, they‚<U+0080><U+0099>re loving, they are erotic, ‚<U+0080>ù Mr. Zwirner said a week later, as the works were being uncrated in New York. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Maybe for me the most shocking reality around this new body of work is that they‚<U+0080><U+0099>re extremely political by not being overtly political. To make it about us, about love, desire and eroticism ‚<U+0080><U+0094> the themes that will maybe help us to get out of the political mess we got ourselves into ‚<U+0080><U+0094> I find extremely powerful.‚<U+0080>ù The Zwirner show is Ms. Dumas‚<U+0080><U+0099>s first major solo presentation since her critically acclaimed 2014-15 retrospective, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The Image as Burden, ‚<U+0080>ù presented at the Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam, the Tate Modern in London and the Beyeler Foundation in Basel, Switzerland. She said it took months to shake off the psychological and emotional reverberations of co-curating the retrospective, which opened just after she‚<U+0080><U+0099>d turned 60 and included artworks from the mid-1970s. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Retrospectives are the worst; they are really killing, ‚<U+0080>ù she said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>You‚<U+0080><U+0099>re all the time busy with what you have done. You become a clich√© of yourself because you have to say who you are all the time, ‚<U+0080>ù she added. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>As an artist, you are always who you are until you go make new work ‚<U+0080><U+0094> and then you are someone else.‚<U+0080>ù For the retrospective, she had hoped to produce new artworks but found it utterly impossible. But then the Moroccan-Dutch writer Hafid Bouazza asked Ms. Dumas to contribute illustrations for a book of Dutch translations of ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Venus and Adonis, ‚<U+0080>ù one of the Shakespeare‚<U+0080><U+0099>s earliest works. It tells the tragic, sometimes funny, often erotic story of Venus‚<U+0080><U+0099> attempts to seduce Adonis, a handsome young mortal. He chooses instead to hunt and is killed. Ms. Dumas approached the project by reading Shakespeare in the English original and in Dutch translation (her native tongue is Afrikaans) as well as Ovid‚<U+0080><U+0099>s version from ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The Metamorphoses.‚<U+0080>ù She also explored historical depictions of Venus and Adonis from antiquity to the present. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It was difficult to decide how to go about it, because you had to think, ‚<U+0080><U+0098>what type of figure, what type of woman am I going to choose for this Venus?‚<U+0080><U+0099> ‚<U+0080>ù she said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>In the old paintings, she was mostly painted as these blonde, voluptuous women, and Shakespeare was writing about a kind of Mediterranean type.‚<U+0080>ù Advertisement The resulting images are black ink wash on various types of paper reduced to essential elements of form. In one image, Venus is voluptuous with long, possibly blonde hair. In another, she might be an African woman with dark curly hair. In yet another, she appears like a vampire, with hollowed out eyes, inspired by an Edvard Munch drawing. Ms. Dumas felt that the ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Venus and Adonis‚<U+0080>ù book illustrations could be an entry point into a new series of paintings, though she was at first uncertain. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Then my daughter said, ‚<U+0080><U+0098>You always make your best paintings of me.‚<U+0080><U+0099> I said, ‚<U+0080><U+0098>I‚<U+0080><U+0099>m not going to paint you, I‚<U+0080><U+0099>m scared, and a pregnant lady doesn‚<U+0080><U+0099>t fit into this exhibition.‚<U+0080><U+0099> ‚<U+0080>ù Ms. Dumas has painted her daughter numerous times ‚<U+0080><U+0094> a particularly famous image is her haunting ‚<U+0080><U+009C>The Painter‚<U+0080>ù (1994) in the Museum of Modern Art‚<U+0080><U+0099>s collection, depicting Helena looking sinister at about 4 years old, with her small hands dipped in black and red paint. Helena, now 29, is one of the few models Ms. Dumas has ever allowed in the studio. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>I‚<U+0080><U+0099>m not really interested in real people, ‚<U+0080>ù she said. ‚<U+0080><U+009C>It sounds strange, I know, but it‚<U+0080><U+0099>s because then I can‚<U+0080><U+0099>t do with my figure what I want. It‚<U+0080><U+0099>s more about states and emotions.‚<U+0080>ù Nevertheless, she did begin a portrait of Helena from behind, standing tall in a strong, self-assured stance, which she named ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Amazon.‚<U+0080>ù Later, Ms. Dumas found an image of Inanna ‚<U+0080><U+0094> the goddess of love, fertility and war from Sumerian mythology, who was associated with the planet Venus ‚<U+0080><U+0094> depicted with wings and bird talons for feet. This was a starting point for another monumental nude, but because Helena was now pregnant and very much on the artist‚<U+0080><U+0099>s mind, Ms. Dumas began to work her daughter‚<U+0080><U+0099>s likeness into the image. Taking a sip of wine, Ms. Dumas mused, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>My time is up, and I still haven‚<U+0080><U+0099>t painted a Venus. Well, I have indeed, but she‚<U+0080><U+0099>s pregnant, and she looks like my daughter.‚<U+0080>ù The two quasi-portraits of Helena, ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Amazon‚<U+0080>ù and ‚<U+0080><U+009C>Birth, ‚<U+0080>ù appear in the same room of the Zwirner exhibition. It is all very fitting, since Ms. Dumas‚<U+0080><U+0099>s first grandchild, Eden, was born on April 28, the day the show opened. Luckily, Ms. Dumas had flown to New York to install the exhibit and returned to Amsterdam in time to be there with Helena for the birth. A version of this article appears in print on May 13, 2018, on Page AR31 of the New York edition with the headline: A Radical Artist Turns Toward Love. Order Reprints| Today's Paper|Subscribe

headline: Mets Trade Matt Harvey to Reds for Devin Mesoraco
description: The Mets had seven days to either trade Harvey or release him, and they acquired a player in exchange to fill in for their injured starting catchers.
author: James Wagner
topic_tags: Baseball, Sports Trades, Reds, Mets, Matt Harvey,
text: The Mets and Matt Harvey have finally ó fully ó parted ways. On the clock to trade him before he might become a free agent, the Mets salvaged something out of Harvey, trading him on Tuesday to the team they happen to be facing this week, the Cincinnati Reds. Harvey, one of the best pitchers in baseball less than three years ago, will now be a reclamation project on the worst team in baseball. In exchange for Harvey, the Mets received cash and the oft-injured catcher Devin Mesoraco, who was in the Redsí starting lineup for Tuesday nightís game until the trade was announced just under an hour before first pitch. Mesoraco, 29, then switched clubhouses at Great American Ball Park. Harvey, also 29, will not face his former team this week, as he will join the Reds for their next series in Los Angeles against the Dodgers beginning Thursday. His performance declined significantly after some injuries, and he had struggled mightily both as a starter and as a reliever this season. Harveyís tenure with the Mets came to an end after they designated him for assignment on Saturday following his refusal to take a minor league assignment, which was within his rights. The Mets had seven days to either trade him or release him if he cleared waivers. Tuesdayís deal is essentially a swap of players to fill needs. The Reds entered Tuesday with the worst record in baseball and a pitching staff that was largely to blame. The Mets desired catching help because of injuries to their two starters at the position: Travis díArnaud (who had season-ending Tommy John surgery) and Kevin Plawecki (who is expected to return later this month from a fractured left hand). Their fill-ins, the journeyman Jose Lobaton and the rookie Tomas Nido, combined to hit .156 with zero home runs in 33 games entering Tuesday. Mesoraco has been slightly better; he hit .220 with one home run in 18 games. He was once an All-Star, in 2014, when he hit .273 with 25 home runs. But in the 2015-2017 seasons, he hit .191 in just 95 games because of a litany of health issues including operations on both hips, a broken foot, and surgery on his left shoulder. The Mets are hoping a now-healthy Mesoraco can help. J.P. Ricciardi, a special assistant to the Metsí general manager, told reporters that right fielder Jay Bruce and third baseman Todd Frazier, Mesoracoís former teammates in Cincinnati, had spoken highly of Mesoraco before the trade. Harvey, who wanted to remain a starting pitcher, will now pitch at a home run-friendly stadium in Cincinnati. With some tweaks, the Reds can perhaps fix Harvey and flip him for a better return than Mesoraco could have garnered at the July trade deadline. Other teams were interested in Harvey, but the Reds were aggressive and fit the Metsí needs. The Reds owed Mesoraco just over $13 million this season, the final year on his contract extension, and the Mets owed Harvey $5.6 million this season, the final year before he was eligible for free agency. Each team will only pay the remaining salary for the player they dealt, said a person familiar with the deal, meaning the Mets will not pay extra for Mesoraco. In order to make room for Mesoraco on the active roster, the Mets placed Frazier on the 10-day disabled list with a left hamstring strain. Before Tuesdayís game, Mets Manager Mickey Callaway told reporters that Frazier had been dealing with some discomfort for weeks but that it worsened in Mondayís game. In a sputtering Mets lineup, Frazier had been one of the most consistent threats to get on base. To help, the Mets are expected to call up infield prospect Luis Guillorme from Class-AAA Las Vegas.

headline: Make Catholicism Weird Again
description: The Met Gala and the future of the church.
author: Ross Douthat
topic_tags: Politics, Museum, Party, Fashion, Christianity,1960s, Catholic Church, Sistine Chapel Choir, Cardinal Dolan, Rihanna, Marcel Proust
text: In 1904, during a debate in France over the anticlerical governmentís takeover of church property, a young Marcel Proust wrote an essay for Le Figaro inviting readers to imagine a future in which the Catholic Church vanished completely from his countryís memory, leaving only the bones of French cathedrals as its monuments. Then he further imagined the cultured elites of some future France rediscovering the texts and chants and rubrics of Catholic liturgy, and in a spasm of enraptured aestheticism, restoring the cathedrals and training actors to recreate the Tridentine Rite Mass. In his vision, like devotees of Wagner making pilgrimage, ìcaravans of swells make their way to Ö Amiens, Chartres, Bourges, Laon, Rheims, Rouen, Paris,î and inside Franceís Gothic churches ìthey experience the feeling they once sought in Bayreuth Ö enjoying a work of art in the very setting that had been built for it.î But of course the recreated Catholic liturgy and revived Catholic aesthetic would never be the real thing; the actors might know their roles, and the incense might waft thick, but attendees could ìonly ever be curious dilettantes; try as they might, the soul of times past does not dwell within them.î Proustís essay, lately translated by Catholic traditionalists, came to mind while watching the beautiful and blasphemous spectacle at the Met Gala on Monday night, where a parade of stars and fashionistas swanned about in costumes inspired by the aesthetics of Catholicism, while a wide variety of genuinely Catholic articles, from vestments to tiaras, were displayed in a Met exhibit titled ìHeavenly Bodies: Fashion and the Catholic Imagination.î Like Proustís ìcaravans of swellsî attending liturgical performances, the attendees at the Met were paying a cultural homage to the aesthetic riches of the Roman Church ó when, of course, they werenít sexing them up for shock value. But the spectacle was not exactly Proustís prophecy come to life, because unlike in his thought experiment, Catholicism today remains a living faith ó weakened but hardly gone, with as complicated a relationship to its own traditions as any lapsed-Catholic museum curator or celebrity dressing up as the Maid of Orleans. This complication is apparent in the Catholic response to the Met Gala itself, which consisted of an institutional blessing for the spectacle ó not just Cardinal Timothy Dolan opening the museum exhibit, but the Sistine Chapel Choir performing for the swells and starlets in the evening ó followed by an angry Catholic social-media backlash against the eveningís various impieties. When a living faith gets treated like a museum piece, itís hard for its adherents to know whether to treat the moment as an opportunity for outreach or for outrage. But the complexity runs much deeper, because to the extent that part of the Proustian prophecy has come true, to the extent that elements of the Catholic tradition have turned into archaic curiosities to be rediscovered by aesthetes and donned lewdly by Rihanna, the choices made by the churchís own leaders have played as much of a role as the anticlericalism of Proustís era. It was the churchís own leadership that decided, in the years following the Second Vatican Council, that the attachment to the church as culture had become an impediment to the mission of preaching the gospel in the modern world. It was the leadership that embraced a different approach, in which Catholic Christianity would seek to enter more fully into modern culture, adopting its styles and habits ó modernist and even brutalist church architecture, casual dress, guitar music, a general suburban and Protestant affect, etc. ó in order to effectively transform it from within. It was the leadership that decided that much of what Proust depicted as Catholicismís cultural glory ó the old Mass above all, but also a host of customs and costumes and rituals ó needed to be retired in order to reach people in a more disenchanted age. This idea was hardly absurd in theory; from Roman Empire days through missionary efforts, Christianity had often advanced through inculturation, importing a consistent religious message into varying cultural forms. But Catholicismís attempt to do the same with modern culture since the 1960s has largely seemed to fail. The secular culture welcomed the churchís Protestantization and demystification and even secularization, praised the bishops and theologians who pursued it, and then simply pocketed the concessions and ignored the religious ideas those concessions were supposed to advance. Meanwhile, that same secular world maintained a consistent fascination, from ìThe Exorcistî down to, well, the Met Gala, with all the weirder parts of Catholicism that were supposedly a stumbling block to modernityís conversion. This failure, and how exactly Catholics should interpret it, helps frame the debates roiling the church in the age of Pope Francis. One theory is that the evidence of the last 50 years suggests that modern culture is inherently anti-religious or anti-Catholic in some abiding way, which means the attempt to adopt its cultural forms and ìaccompanyî its denizens will inevitably end in dissolution for the church itself. Thus the only plausible approach for Catholicism is to offer itself, not as a chaplaincy within modern liberalism, but as a full alternative culture in its own right ó one that reclaims the inheritance on display at the Met, glories in its own weirdness and supernaturalism, and spurns both accommodations and entangling alliances (including the ones that conservative Catholics have forged with libertarian-inflected right-wing political movements). The other view is that in fact inculturation has not gone far enough, that the church may have changed its liturgy and costumes, but itís still held back by its abstract dogmas and arid legalisms, and that one final great leap into modernity, a renewed commitment to accompaniment and understanding and adaptation, is necessary for the church to gain what it sought when it began its great demystification project 50 years ago. As pontiff, Francis has been on both sides of these debates. The radicalism of his economic and ecological vision, often portrayed as simply liberal, actually represents a kind of left-leaning pessimism that arguably points backward to the strenuous critiques of modernity issued by 19th-century popes. And at times this radicalism has been matched by his willingness to join conservative members of his flock in culture war ó as recently in the Alfie Evans case in England, where the pope ended up in a public conflict with the more culturally accommodating sort of Catholic over whether to defer to medical professionals and deprive a brain-damaged toddler of oxygen because his life was judged no longer worth sustaining. But only at times; on many other fronts, the Francis era has been a springtime for accommodation and inculturation, and especially for the secularizing and Protestantizing German Catholicism that helped forge the original revolution of the 1960s, and whose leaders believe that only further modernization can refill their empty churches. Under German influence, but with the popeís implicit blessing, Catholic rules on divorce and now perhaps intercommunion may be joining the Latin Mass and meatless Fridays on the altar of sacrifices to the culture of the modern world. Meanwhile in the case of the opulent style of Catholic fashion on display at the Met Gala, it is very clear where Francis stands. As Tara Isabella Burton points out in an astute piece for Vox, itís the popeís traditionalist adversaries who are more likely to don the sort of ìheavenlyî garb being feted and imitated at the Met ó while from his own simple choice of dress to his constant digs at overdressed clerics and fancy traditionalists, the pope believes that baroque Catholicism belongs in a museum or at a costume gala, and that the churchís future lies in the simple, the casual, the austere and the plain. For this, as for his doctrine-shaking innovations, Francis has won admiring press. But as with the last wave of Catholic revolution, there is little evidence that the modernizing project makes moderns into Catholics. (The latest Gallup data, for instance, shows American Mass attendance declining faster in the Francis era.) Instead, the quest for accommodation seems to encourage moderns to divide their sense of what Catholicism represents in two ó into an Old Church thatís frightening and fascinating in equal measure, and a New Church thatís a little more liked but much more easily ignored. Francis and other would-be modernizers are right, and have always been right, that Catholic Christianity should not trade on fear. But a religion that claims to be divinely established cannot persuade without a lot of fascination, and far too much of that has been given up, consigned to the museum, as Western Catholicism has traced its slow decline. Here the Met Gala should offer the faith from which it took its theme a little bit of inspiration. The path forward for the Catholic Church in the modern world is extraordinarily uncertain. But there is no plausible path that does not involve more of what was displayed and appropriated and blasphemed against in New York City Monday night, more of what once made Catholicism both great and weird, and could yet make it both again.

headline: The Water Will Come, but Not to This Miami Home
description: The cityís flooding is expected to get worse as sea levels rise. So a Michigan man has built a house in South Beach that should withstand the water.
author: Brett Sokol
topic_tags: Real Estate and Housing, Architecture, Interior Design, Flood
text: A 21st-century Atlantis-in-the-making is how many scientists think of Miami Beach. With a projected sea-level rise of three to four feet by the centuryís end, huge chunks of the barrier-island city are expected to lie beneath the Atlantic Ocean. But Hany Boutros is staying. In fact, Mr. Boutros, 43, a Detroit-area health care executive and real estate developer, has built a new 3,500-square-foot home in South Beach, the cityís most threatened neighborhood. ìI would be foolish if I didnít take sea-level rise into consideration, but itís not going to stop me from living the life I want,î he said, standing inside his Prairie Avenue homeís entryway. ìI found a solution,î he added, motioning to the retractable automated stairway that connects a 9,400-square-foot open-air gated tropical garden and parking area with the three-bedroom house above it. Designed by the Miami architect Rene Gonzalez as the first in a series of luxury ìelevated housesî around South Florida, it has been built to allow up to 10 feet of storm surge to safely flow underneath it. ìThe house already went through a test when Irma hit,î Mr. Boutros said, referring to the hurricane that swamped greater Miami in September. It was reported that Irmaís 185-mile-an-hour winds had largely spared the area, but it was a different story on the ground. Wind-driven rain flooded the ultramodern high rises and Art Deco hotels alike; two feet of water sloshed through some neighborhoods, while others were left without electricity for weeks. Back in Michigan, Mr. Boutros was poking around Facebook, desperate for a post-Irma update on how his new house had fared. ìI saw a nearby neighbor posting pictures of flooding and tree damage as she walked around,î he said. Mr. Boutros messaged her, gave her the access codes to the control panels that essentially run his home and asked her to step inside it. The rest of the street had lost power, but his front gate opened, and the retractable staircase smoothly descended 10 feet on its system of pulleys and cables. ìBecause I have a generator that turns on automatically, the house ended up being a shelter. I said, ëBring your friends, bring your kids, thereís hot water for showers ó please use it!í I had zero damages. It was as if Irma went around my house,î he said. That was no accident, Mr. Gonzalez said. ìRather than fighting the situation, we have to create spaces that allow us to live in a way that is closer to the environment, closer to the way the Seminole Indians in Florida lived,î with their Chickee huts up off the ground on stilts, protecting against water and allowing ventilating breezes to blow through. Mr. Gonzalez has taken that same approach to the glass walls of this homeís living room. They act as pocket doors, entirely sliding away to create another open-air space. Unlike many of his contemporaries, Mr. Gonzalez used glass sparingly. With the homeís overall cost at $1,700 a square foot, exposed and treated concrete dominates ìwith planes that just float, without gravity, if you will.î ìThe walls donít touch the floor. They go up beyond the ceiling, appearing to continue to the sky. It gives you the effect of infinite space.î Miami artists also feature prominently. In the dining room, a massive sculpture by Sinisa Kukec resembles two golden raindrops plinking into puddles. One guest bedroom displays an abstract painting by Lynne Golob Gelfman, the other a drawing by Michele Oka Doner. Separate control panels allow guests to access these rooms and come and go on their own, even if other parts of the home remain locked. While Mr. Gonzalez praised Miami Beach officials for tackling sea-level rise with a $500 million street-raising and pumping project (one that is being re-evaluated amid concerns that plans for further elevated roads may actually worsen flooding of adjoining homes and businesses in the short term), he said he was frustrated with many in the real estate community. Some architects seem happy to take their wedding cake-style McMansions and jack them up on stilts, he noted, regardless of what he calls the poor aesthetics. And some developers still seem to be in denial. That much was clear in Jeff Goodellís 2017 book ìThe Water Will Come: Rising Seas, Sinking Cities, and the Remaking of the Civilized World.î Mr. Goodell wrote of cornering Jorge PÈrez at an event honoring Ms. Oka Doner inside his namesake PÈrez Art Museum Miami. Ms. Oka Doner had already sold her Miami Beach home, convinced that it would soon be underwater. Mr. PÈrez, one of South Floridaís largest condo developers, was more skeptical. Asked by Mr. Goodell if sea-level rise had altered his business thinking, he replied curtly that it hadnít. Pressed, Mr. PÈrez said, ìIn 20 or 30 years, someone is going to find a solution for this.î He added, ìBesides, by that time, Iíll be dead, so what does it matter?î For his part, Mr. Boutros said the rising sea wasnít his only concern. Raised in Lebanon before he moved to Detroit to attend college, Mr. Boutros said he practically lived on Beirutís shoreline. Sun-dappled Miami Beach was a homecoming of sorts, but he was aware of security issues. Hence the retractable staircase. ìIím not here 24/7,î he said. ìHow do we make sure thereís no access to the house?î With a chuckle, he added, ìPlus, I wanted something out of James Bond, something sexy.î The same playfully louche theme carries through to his master bedroom, where a large doorless shower with transparent glass walls occupies the center of the room. This is not a home for anyone, or their overnight guests, who is bashful about disrobing. ìIf someone is with you in this room and youíre not comfortable being naked with them, they shouldnít be in this room,î Mr. Boutros said. ìWhatís the difference between standing naked in the middle of the room and being naked in bed?î Mr. Boutros wasnít waiting for a reply. He was already bounding up a staircase that led from his bedroom to a roof deck. Open on one side except for a barely there railing, it too was not for the cautious.
